content.text: I'll help you build the Organizer v1.0 by first reviewing the implementation plan. Let me start by reading the plan document.

content.content:
1→# Organizer Version 1.0 Implementation Plan
     2→
     3→## Executive Summary
     4→
     5→### Problem Statement
     6→Users currently have no way to organize, categorize, or efficiently locate previously uploaded documents in the Bookkeeper application. Files exist only as an unstructured list from the upload system, making document discovery time-consuming and inefficient, particularly for legal professionals who need to quickly locate specific documents among hundreds or thousands of uploaded files.
     7→
     8→### Solution Overview
     9→Implement a basic file listing interface with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with fundamental document organization through text-based tags and simple search functionality.
    10→
    11→## Core Goal
    12→
    13→Create a simple file list view with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with basic document organization through text-based tags.
    14→
    15→## Architecture Overview
    16→
    17→### Two-Database Design
    18→
    19→1. **Storage 1: Uploads** (Existing) - Raw file storage in Firebase Storage
    20→   - Contains actual file bytes stored by hash
    21→   - Maintains upload metadata for deduplication
    22→   - Single source of truth for file content
    23→
    24→2. **Database 2: Evidence** (New) - Organizer's core database
    25→   - References files in Storage 1 via fileHash
    26→   - Maintains all organizational metadata (tags, categories)
    27→   - Supports future processing workflow states
    28→   - Enables multiple evidence entries pointing to same file
    29→
    30→### Key Design Decisions
    31→- Evidence database is separate from upload metadata
    32→- One uploaded file can have multiple evidence entries (different matters, different tags)
    33→- Evidence entries reference storage files, never duplicate them
    34→- Processing status fields included but unused in v1.0 (future-proofing)
    35→
    36→## Features to Implement
    37→
    38→### 1. Basic File List View
    39→- Display all uploaded files with metadata (filename, extension, upload date)
    40→- Integration with existing Firebase storage system
    41→- Simple table/list interface using Vuetify components
    42→
    43→### 2. Manual Tag Assignment
    44→- Tag input interface for each file (text-based input)
    45→- Tags stored as array of strings in Firestore
    46→- Ability to add/remove tags per file
    47→
    48→### 3. Basic Search/Filter
    49→- Text-based filtering by tag names
    50→- Simple search interface at top of file list
    51→- Real-time filtering as user types
    52→
    53→### 4. Navigation Integration
    54→- New "Organizer" route and navigation item
    55→- Proper Vue Router integration
    56→- Route guards for authenticated access
    57→
    58→## Technical Architecture
    59→
    60→### Data Model
    61→```javascript
    62→// NEW: Evidence Database Structure (Database 2: Evidence)
    63→// Collection: /teams/{teamId}/evidence/{evidenceId}
    64→{
    65→  evidenceId: "auto-generated", // Firestore auto-ID
    66→  teamId: "user-team-id",
    67→  
    68→  // Reference to actual file in Storage 1
    69→  storageRef: {
    70→    storage: "uploads", // or "split", "merged" in future versions
    71→    fileHash: "abc123...", // Points to file in Storage 1
    72→    matterId: "general", // Which matter folder in storage
    73→  },
    74→  
    75→  // Evidence metadata
    76→  displayName: "Bank Statement March 2024.pdf", // User-friendly name
    77→  originalName: "statement_03_2024.pdf", // Original upload name
    78→  fileExtension: ".pdf",
    79→  fileSize: 245632,
    80→  
    81→  // Processing status (for future Document Processing Workflow)
    82→  isProcessed: false, // Will be true after v2.0 processing
    83→  hasAllPages: null, // null = unknown, true/false after processing
    84→  processingStage: "uploaded", // uploaded|splitting|merging|complete
    85→  
    86→  // Organization (v1.0 focus)
    87→  tags: ["bank-statement", "2024", "march"],
    88→  tagCount: 3,
    89→  lastTaggedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
    90→  taggedBy: "manual", // "manual" | "auto" in future
    91→  
    92→  // Timestamps
    93→  createdAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
    94→  updatedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"
    95→}
    96→```
    97→
    98→### Component Structure
    99→```
   100→views/
   101→  Organizer.vue                 // Main organizer page
   102→components/features/organizer/
   103→  FileList.vue                  // File list display component
   104→  FileListItem.vue              // Individual file row component
   105→  TagInput.vue                  // Tag input/management component
   106→  FileFilter.vue                // Search/filter interface
   107→```
   108→
   109→### Store Integration
   110→```javascript
   111→// New Pinia store for organizer functionality
   112→stores/organizer.js
   113→- fileList: [] // Array of file objects with tags
   114→- filteredFiles: [] // Computed filtered results
   115→- filterText: "" // Current filter string
   116→- actions: fetchFiles(), updateFileTags(), filterFiles()
   117→```
   118→
   119→## Existing Codebase Assessment
   120→
   121→### Current Organizer Files (Lines of Code)
   122→- `FileListItem.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)
   123→- `FileSearch.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)  
   124→- `useFileSearch.js`: 44 lines (partial implementation with basic search logic)
   125→- Additional skeleton files: `FileGrid.vue`, `FilePreview.vue`, `FileDetails.vue`, `ViewModeToggle.vue`, `FileTypeFilters.vue` (all basic skeletons)
   126→- Composables: `useFileViewer.js`, `useFilePreview.js`, `useViewerNavigation.js` (skeleton files)
   127→- Utils: `fileViewerUtils.js`, `previewGenerators.js` (skeleton files)
   128→
   129→**Total Existing**: ~15 skeleton files with approximately 200 lines of placeholder code
   130→
   131→### Integration Points
   132→- Existing upload system uses hash-based file identification
   133→- Firebase Storage already configured and working
   134→- Authentication system with team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
   135→- Vuetify components and styling system established
   136→
   137→## Implementation Steps
   138→
   139→### Step 1: Data Layer Setup (High Complexity)
   140→**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium  
   141→**Dependencies**: None  
   142→**Internet Research Summary**: Based on Firebase documentation and 2024 best practices, optimal Firestore collection patterns recommend using lowerCamelCase field names, avoiding sequential document IDs to prevent hotspots, and implementing subcollections for hierarchical data. For file metadata, the recommendation is to denormalize data for query performance while keeping documents under 1MB. The pattern of using hash-based IDs (already implemented in upload system) aligns with best practices for avoiding monotonically increasing IDs that can cause latency issues.
   143→
   144→**Rollback Mechanism**: All data model changes are additive only. Evidence collection can be deleted without affecting upload functionality. Firestore security rules can be reverted to previous state if needed.
   145→
   146→- [ ] Create new Evidence collection in Firestore at `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
   147→- [ ] Design evidence document schema with storage references
   148→- [ ] Create migration script to populate Evidence from existing uploads:
   149→  ```javascript
   150→  // Migration approach:
   151→  // 1. Query all existing files in /teams/{teamId}/matters/*/metadata/
   152→  // 2. For each unique fileHash, create one Evidence entry
   153→  // 3. Set storageRef to point to existing file location
   154→  // 4. Initialize with empty tags array and isProcessed: false
   155→  ```
   156→- [ ] Update Firestore security rules for Evidence collection
   157→- [ ] Create Pinia store for evidence management (separate from upload store)
   158→
   159→### Step 2: Core Components (Low Complexity)
   160→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   161→**Dependencies**: Step 1 (data layer)  
   162→
   163→- [ ] Enhance existing `Organizer.vue` view component  
   164→- [ ] Build `FileList.vue` component for displaying files
   165→- [ ] Complete implementation of existing `FileListItem.vue` skeleton (currently 16 lines)
   166→- [ ] Create `TagInput.vue` component for tag management
   167→
   168→### Step 3: Tag Management System (High Complexity)
   169→**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium
   170→**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 2  
   171→**Internet Research Summary**: Vue 3 tag input best practices for 2024 recommend using established UI libraries (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Shadcn/Vue) for production applications. Vuetify's chip component provides built-in accessibility with proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation. Custom implementations should leverage Composition API with composable patterns for reusability. The recommended pattern includes reactive tag arrays, input validation, and proper event handling for add/remove operations.
   172→
   173→**Rollback Mechanism**: Tag functionality can be disabled via feature flag. Firestore writes for tags can be wrapped in try/catch with rollback to previous tag state on failure.
   174→
   175→- [ ] Implement tag input interface with add/remove functionality
   176→- [ ] Create tag display with visual indicators using Vuetify chips
   177→- [ ] Add tag persistence to Firestore
   178→- [ ] Implement optimistic UI updates for tag changes
   179→
   180→### Step 4: Search and Filter (Low Complexity)  
   181→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low
   182→**Dependencies**: Step 2, Step 3  
   183→
   184→- [ ] Complete existing `FileSearch.vue` skeleton component (currently 16 lines)
   185→- [ ] Enhance existing `useFileSearch.js` composable (currently 44 lines with basic logic)
   186→- [ ] Implement real-time filtering logic in store
   187→- [ ] Add filter state management and persistence
   188→
   189→### Step 5: Navigation and Routing (Low Complexity)
   190→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   191→**Dependencies**: Step 2
   192→
   193→- [ ] Add "Organizer" route to Vue Router configuration
   194→- [ ] Update navigation sidebar with Organizer link  
   195→- [ ] Implement route guards for authentication
   196→- [ ] Add proper page titles and meta information
   197→
   198→### Step 6: Integration with Existing System (High Complexity)
   199→**Breaking Risk Level**: High  
   200→**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 5  
   201→**Internet Research Summary**: VueFire (official Vue.js Firebase bindings) provides the recommended 2024 approach for Firebase Storage integration with Vue 3. The `useStorageFile()`, `useStorageFileUrl()`, and `useStorageFileMetadata()` composables offer reactive bindings that automatically sync metadata changes. The pattern involves importing composables from VueFire and using reactive references for file operations, which aligns with our existing Firebase setup.
   202→
   203→**Rollback Mechanism**: Integration changes can be isolated behind feature flags. Existing upload functionality remains unchanged. If metadata sync fails, system falls back to upload-only mode. Database queries can be reverted to original upload system patterns.
   204→
   205→- [ ] Connect to existing Firebase storage system using VueFire patterns
   206→- [ ] Leverage existing file upload metadata without breaking current functionality
   207→- [ ] Ensure team-based data isolation maintains existing security model
   208→- [ ] Test integration with existing authentication system
   209→
   210→### Step 7: Testing and Polish (Medium Complexity)
   211→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   212→**Dependencies**: All previous steps  
   213→
   214→- [ ] Write unit tests for new components  
   215→- [ ] Add E2E tests for organizer workflow
   216→- [ ] Test with large file collections
   217→- [ ] Performance optimization and loading states
   218→
   219→## File Structure
   220→
   221→### Files to Enhance (Already Exist as Skeletons)
   222→```
   223→src/features/organizer/
   224→├── components/
   225→│   ├── FileListItem.vue (16 lines → enhance)
   226→│   ├── FileSearch.vue (16 lines → enhance)  
   227→│   ├── FileGrid.vue (skeleton → enhance for list view)
   228→│   └── FileDetails.vue (skeleton → enhance for tag display)
   229→├── composables/
   230→│   ├── useFileSearch.js (44 lines → enhance)
   231→│   └── useFileViewer.js (skeleton → enhance)
   232→└── views/
   233→    └── FileViewer.vue (skeleton → repurpose as main Organizer view)
   234→```
   235→
   236→### New Files to Create
   237→```
   238→src/features/organizer/
   239→├── components/
   240→│   └── TagInput.vue (new)
   241→├── stores/
   242→│   └── organizer.js (new)
   243→├── services/
   244→│   └── organizerService.js (new)
   245→└── composables/
   246→    └── useOrganizer.js (new)
   247→```
   248→
   249→## User Interface Design
   250→
   251→### Layout Structure
   252→- Header with search/filter bar
   253→- Main content area with file list table
   254→- Each row shows: filename, file type icon, upload date, tags, actions
   255→- Tag display as small chips/badges
   256→- Inline tag editing capability
   257→
   258→### Vuetify Components
   259→- `v-data-table` or `v-list` for file listing
   260→- `v-chip` for tag display
   261→- `v-text-field` for search and tag input
   262→- `v-icon` for file type indicators
   263→- `v-card` for overall layout container
   264→
   265→## Data Flow
   266→
   267→1. **File Loading**: Organizer store fetches file metadata from Firestore on mount
   268→2. **Tag Assignment**: User clicks tag input → opens inline editor → saves to Firestore → updates local state
   269→3. **Filtering**: User types in search → store computes filtered results → UI updates reactively
   270→4. **Tag Management**: Add/remove tags → optimistic UI update → Firestore write → error handling
   271→
   272→## Testing Strategy
   273→
   274→### Unit Tests
   275→- Store actions and getters
   276→- Component prop handling and events
   277→- Tag input validation and formatting
   278→- Filter logic correctness
   279→
   280→### Integration Tests
   281→- Firestore data operations
   282→- Authentication integration
   283→- Route navigation and guards
   284→- Cross-component data flow
   285→
   286→### E2E Tests
   287→- Complete organizer workflow
   288→- Tag assignment and search
   289→- Integration with existing upload system
   290→- Performance with multiple files
   291→
   292→## Single Source of Truth Compliance
   293→
   294→### Data Architecture
   295→- **Primary Source**: Existing upload system hash-based file identification remains authoritative
   296→- **Metadata Extension**: Tags stored as additional field in existing file documents, not separate collection
   297→- **Firestore Integration**: Leverages existing file metadata structure to avoid duplication
   298→- **No Data Duplication**: Tag data extends existing documents rather than creating parallel storage
   299→
   300→### Reference Integration
   301→- File metadata continues using existing Firebase Storage references
   302→- Tag data stored in same Firestore documents as existing upload metadata
   303→- Upload system remains unchanged and authoritative for file operations
   304→- Organizer reads from single source rather than creating separate data stores
   305→
   306→## Performance Considerations
   307→
   308→### Initial Implementation (v1.0 Scope Only)
   309→- Simple approach suitable for moderate file collections (100-1000 files)
   310→- Client-side filtering for responsive UI
   311→- Basic loading states during data fetch
   312→- **No premature optimization** - defer performance enhancements to later versions
   313→
   314→### Explicitly Deferred to Future Versions
   315→- Virtual scrolling for large collections (planned for v1.9)
   316→- Server-side filtering for very large datasets  
   317→- Lazy loading of file metadata
   318→- Caching strategies for frequently accessed data
   319→
   320→## Security Requirements
   321→
   322→### Firestore Rules
   323→```javascript
   324→// Ensure users can only access their own team's files
   325→rules_version = '2';
   326→service cloud.firestore {
   327→  match /databases/{database}/documents {
   328→    match /fileMetadata/{fileId} {
   329→      allow read, write: if request.auth != null 
   330→        && resource.data.teamId == request.auth.uid;
   331→    }
   332→  }
   333→}
   334→```
   335→
   336→### Data Validation
   337→- Sanitize tag input to prevent XSS
   338→- Validate file access permissions
   339→- Ensure team isolation in all operations
   340→
   341→## Migration Strategy
   342→
   343→### Existing File Indexing
   344→```javascript
   345→// On first Organizer access:
   346→// 1. Check if user has un-indexed files (files without taggedBy field)
   347→// 2. Batch create/update metadata documents with empty tags array
   348→// 3. Show one-time "Indexing files..." progress modal
   349→// 4. Set taggedBy: "manual" and tagCount: 0 for all existing files
   350→// 5. Cache indexing completion in localStorage to avoid re-runs
   351→```
   352→
   353→## Integration Points
   354→
   355→### Existing Systems
   356→- **Upload System**: Leverage existing file metadata and hash-based deduplication
   357→- **Authentication**: Use existing team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
   358→- **Storage**: Connect to existing Firebase Storage for file access
   359→- **Routing**: Integrate with existing Vue Router and navigation
   360→
   361→### Future Versions
   362→- Tag structure extensible to category-based system (v1.1)
   363→- Component architecture supports AI integration (v1.3)
   364→- Data model compatible with confidence scoring (v1.4)
   365→- UI framework supports virtual folder views (v1.2)
   366→
   367→## Success Criteria
   368→
   369→### Functional Requirements
   370→- [ ] Users can view all uploaded files in organized list
   371→- [ ] Users can assign text-based tags to any file
   372→- [ ] Users can search/filter files by tag text
   373→- [ ] System maintains existing upload functionality
   374→- [ ] All operations respect team-based data isolation
   375→
   376→### Performance Requirements
   377→- [ ] File list loads within 2 seconds for 100 files
   378→- [ ] Tag filtering responds within 500ms
   379→- [ ] Tag assignment saves within 1 second
   380→- [ ] UI remains responsive during all operations
   381→
   382→### User Experience Requirements
   383→- [ ] Intuitive interface requiring minimal learning
   384→- [ ] Consistent with existing application design patterns
   385→- [ ] Clear visual feedback for all user actions
   386→- [ ] Graceful error handling and recovery
   387→
   388→## Risk Mitigation
   389→
   390→### Technical Risks
   391→- **Large File Collections**: Start with client-side filtering, monitor performance
   392→- **Concurrent Tag Updates**: Implement optimistic updates with rollback capability
   393→- **Firestore Costs**: Monitor query patterns and implement pagination if needed
   394→
   395→### User Experience Risks
   396→- **Feature Discoverability**: Clear navigation and introductory help text
   397→- **Tag Management Complexity**: Keep v1.0 simple, defer advanced features to later versions
   398→- **Data Migration**: Ensure existing uploaded files are properly indexed
   399→
   400→## Documentation Requirements
   401→
   402→### Developer Documentation
   403→- Component API documentation
   404→- Store structure and actions
   405→- Data model and relationships
   406→- Testing guidelines and examples
   407→
   408→### User Documentation
   409→- Feature introduction and benefits
   410→- Step-by-step usage guide
   411→- Tag best practices
   412→- Integration with existing workflow
   413→
   414→## Deployment Strategy
   415→
   416→### Development Phases
   417→1. **Local Development**: Build and test all components in isolation
   418→2. **Integration Testing**: Test with existing system on development Firebase
   419→3. **User Acceptance Testing**: Deploy to staging environment for feedback
   420→4. **Production Deployment**: Roll out with feature flag capability
   421→
   422→### Rollback Plan
   423→- Feature toggle for organizer navigation item
   424→- Database schema changes are additive only
   425→- Component lazy loading allows graceful fallback
   426→- Separate service worker for organizer-specific functionality
   427→
   428→## Timeline Estimation
   429→
   430→### Week 1: Foundation
   431→- Data model design and Firestore setup
   432→- Basic component structure
   433→- Store implementation and integration
   434→
   435→### Week 2: Core Features
   436→- File list display and tag input
   437→- Basic search/filter functionality
   438→- Navigation integration
   439→
   440→### Week 3: Polish and Testing
   441→- UI refinement and responsive design
   442→- Comprehensive testing suite
   443→- Performance optimization and error handling
   444→
   445→### Total Estimated Duration: 3 weeks
   446→
   447→This implementation plan provides the foundation for all future Organizer versions while delivering immediate value through manual document organization capabilities.

file.content:
# Organizer Version 1.0 Implementation Plan

## Executive Summary

### Problem Statement
Users currently have no way to organize, categorize, or efficiently locate previously uploaded documents in the Bookkeeper application. Files exist only as an unstructured list from the upload system, making document discovery time-consuming and inefficient, particularly for legal professionals who need to quickly locate specific documents among hundreds or thousands of uploaded files.

### Solution Overview
Implement a basic file listing interface with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with fundamental document organization through text-based tags and simple search functionality.

## Core Goal

Create a simple file list view with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with basic document organization through text-based tags.

## Architecture Overview

### Two-Database Design

1. **Storage 1: Uploads** (Existing) - Raw file storage in Firebase Storage
   - Contains actual file bytes stored by hash
   - Maintains upload metadata for deduplication
   - Single source of truth for file content

2. **Database 2: Evidence** (New) - Organizer's core database
   - References files in Storage 1 via fileHash
   - Maintains all organizational metadata (tags, categories)
   - Supports future processing workflow states
   - Enables multiple evidence entries pointing to same file

### Key Design Decisions
- Evidence database is separate from upload metadata
- One uploaded file can have multiple evidence entries (different matters, different tags)
- Evidence entries reference storage files, never duplicate them
- Processing status fields included but unused in v1.0 (future-proofing)

## Features to Implement

### 1. Basic File List View
- Display all uploaded files with metadata (filename, extension, upload date)
- Integration with existing Firebase storage system
- Simple table/list interface using Vuetify components

### 2. Manual Tag Assignment
- Tag input interface for each file (text-based input)
- Tags stored as array of strings in Firestore
- Ability to add/remove tags per file

### 3. Basic Search/Filter
- Text-based filtering by tag names
- Simple search interface at top of file list
- Real-time filtering as user types

### 4. Navigation Integration
- New "Organizer" route and navigation item
- Proper Vue Router integration
- Route guards for authenticated access

## Technical Architecture

### Data Model
```javascript
// NEW: Evidence Database Structure (Database 2: Evidence)
// Collection: /teams/{teamId}/evidence/{evidenceId}
{
  evidenceId: "auto-generated", // Firestore auto-ID
  teamId: "user-team-id",
  
  // Reference to actual file in Storage 1
  storageRef: {
    storage: "uploads", // or "split", "merged" in future versions
    fileHash: "abc123...", // Points to file in Storage 1
    matterId: "general", // Which matter folder in storage
  },
  
  // Evidence metadata
  displayName: "Bank Statement March 2024.pdf", // User-friendly name
  originalName: "statement_03_2024.pdf", // Original upload name
  fileExtension: ".pdf",
  fileSize: 245632,
  
  // Processing status (for future Document Processing Workflow)
  isProcessed: false, // Will be true after v2.0 processing
  hasAllPages: null, // null = unknown, true/false after processing
  processingStage: "uploaded", // uploaded|splitting|merging|complete
  
  // Organization (v1.0 focus)
  tags: ["bank-statement", "2024", "march"],
  tagCount: 3,
  lastTaggedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  taggedBy: "manual", // "manual" | "auto" in future
  
  // Timestamps
  createdAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  updatedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"
}
```

### Component Structure
```
views/
  Organizer.vue                 // Main organizer page
components/features/organizer/
  FileList.vue                  // File list display component
  FileListItem.vue              // Individual file row component
  TagInput.vue                  // Tag input/management component
  FileFilter.vue                // Search/filter interface
```

### Store Integration
```javascript
// New Pinia store for organizer functionality
stores/organizer.js
- fileList: [] // Array of file objects with tags
- filteredFiles: [] // Computed filtered results
- filterText: "" // Current filter string
- actions: fetchFiles(), updateFileTags(), filterFiles()
```

## Existing Codebase Assessment

### Current Organizer Files (Lines of Code)
- `FileListItem.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)
- `FileSearch.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)  
- `useFileSearch.js`: 44 lines (partial implementation with basic search logic)
- Additional skeleton files: `FileGrid.vue`, `FilePreview.vue`, `FileDetails.vue`, `ViewModeToggle.vue`, `FileTypeFilters.vue` (all basic skeletons)
- Composables: `useFileViewer.js`, `useFilePreview.js`, `useViewerNavigation.js` (skeleton files)
- Utils: `fileViewerUtils.js`, `previewGenerators.js` (skeleton files)

**Total Existing**: ~15 skeleton files with approximately 200 lines of placeholder code

### Integration Points
- Existing upload system uses hash-based file identification
- Firebase Storage already configured and working
- Authentication system with team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- Vuetify components and styling system established

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Data Layer Setup (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium  
**Dependencies**: None  
**Internet Research Summary**: Based on Firebase documentation and 2024 best practices, optimal Firestore collection patterns recommend using lowerCamelCase field names, avoiding sequential document IDs to prevent hotspots, and implementing subcollections for hierarchical data. For file metadata, the recommendation is to denormalize data for query performance while keeping documents under 1MB. The pattern of using hash-based IDs (already implemented in upload system) aligns with best practices for avoiding monotonically increasing IDs that can cause latency issues.

**Rollback Mechanism**: All data model changes are additive only. Evidence collection can be deleted without affecting upload functionality. Firestore security rules can be reverted to previous state if needed.

- [ ] Create new Evidence collection in Firestore at `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
- [ ] Design evidence document schema with storage references
- [ ] Create migration script to populate Evidence from existing uploads:
  ```javascript
  // Migration approach:
  // 1. Query all existing files in /teams/{teamId}/matters/*/metadata/
  // 2. For each unique fileHash, create one Evidence entry
  // 3. Set storageRef to point to existing file location
  // 4. Initialize with empty tags array and isProcessed: false
  ```
- [ ] Update Firestore security rules for Evidence collection
- [ ] Create Pinia store for evidence management (separate from upload store)

### Step 2: Core Components (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 1 (data layer)  

- [ ] Enhance existing `Organizer.vue` view component  
- [ ] Build `FileList.vue` component for displaying files
- [ ] Complete implementation of existing `FileListItem.vue` skeleton (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Create `TagInput.vue` component for tag management

### Step 3: Tag Management System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 2  
**Internet Research Summary**: Vue 3 tag input best practices for 2024 recommend using established UI libraries (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Shadcn/Vue) for production applications. Vuetify's chip component provides built-in accessibility with proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation. Custom implementations should leverage Composition API with composable patterns for reusability. The recommended pattern includes reactive tag arrays, input validation, and proper event handling for add/remove operations.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Tag functionality can be disabled via feature flag. Firestore writes for tags can be wrapped in try/catch with rollback to previous tag state on failure.

- [ ] Implement tag input interface with add/remove functionality
- [ ] Create tag display with visual indicators using Vuetify chips
- [ ] Add tag persistence to Firestore
- [ ] Implement optimistic UI updates for tag changes

### Step 4: Search and Filter (Low Complexity)  
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low
**Dependencies**: Step 2, Step 3  

- [ ] Complete existing `FileSearch.vue` skeleton component (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Enhance existing `useFileSearch.js` composable (currently 44 lines with basic logic)
- [ ] Implement real-time filtering logic in store
- [ ] Add filter state management and persistence

### Step 5: Navigation and Routing (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 2

- [ ] Add "Organizer" route to Vue Router configuration
- [ ] Update navigation sidebar with Organizer link  
- [ ] Implement route guards for authentication
- [ ] Add proper page titles and meta information

### Step 6: Integration with Existing System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: High  
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 5  
**Internet Research Summary**: VueFire (official Vue.js Firebase bindings) provides the recommended 2024 approach for Firebase Storage integration with Vue 3. The `useStorageFile()`, `useStorageFileUrl()`, and `useStorageFileMetadata()` composables offer reactive bindings that automatically sync metadata changes. The pattern involves importing composables from VueFire and using reactive references for file operations, which aligns with our existing Firebase setup.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Integration changes can be isolated behind feature flags. Existing upload functionality remains unchanged. If metadata sync fails, system falls back to upload-only mode. Database queries can be reverted to original upload system patterns.

- [ ] Connect to existing Firebase storage system using VueFire patterns
- [ ] Leverage existing file upload metadata without breaking current functionality
- [ ] Ensure team-based data isolation maintains existing security model
- [ ] Test integration with existing authentication system

### Step 7: Testing and Polish (Medium Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: All previous steps  

- [ ] Write unit tests for new components  
- [ ] Add E2E tests for organizer workflow
- [ ] Test with large file collections
- [ ] Performance optimization and loading states

## File Structure

### Files to Enhance (Already Exist as Skeletons)
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   ├── FileListItem.vue (16 lines → enhance)
│   ├── FileSearch.vue (16 lines → enhance)  
│   ├── FileGrid.vue (skeleton → enhance for list view)
│   └── FileDetails.vue (skeleton → enhance for tag display)
├── composables/
│   ├── useFileSearch.js (44 lines → enhance)
│   └── useFileViewer.js (skeleton → enhance)
└── views/
    └── FileViewer.vue (skeleton → repurpose as main Organizer view)
```

### New Files to Create
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   └── TagInput.vue (new)
├── stores/
│   └── organizer.js (new)
├── services/
│   └── organizerService.js (new)
└── composables/
    └── useOrganizer.js (new)
```

## User Interface Design

### Layout Structure
- Header with search/filter bar
- Main content area with file list table
- Each row shows: filename, file type icon, upload date, tags, actions
- Tag display as small chips/badges
- Inline tag editing capability

### Vuetify Components
- `v-data-table` or `v-list` for file listing
- `v-chip` for tag display
- `v-text-field` for search and tag input
- `v-icon` for file type indicators
- `v-card` for overall layout container

## Data Flow

1. **File Loading**: Organizer store fetches file metadata from Firestore on mount
2. **Tag Assignment**: User clicks tag input → opens inline editor → saves to Firestore → updates local state
3. **Filtering**: User types in search → store computes filtered results → UI updates reactively
4. **Tag Management**: Add/remove tags → optimistic UI update → Firestore write → error handling

## Testing Strategy

### Unit Tests
- Store actions and getters
- Component prop handling and events
- Tag input validation and formatting
- Filter logic correctness

### Integration Tests
- Firestore data operations
- Authentication integration
- Route navigation and guards
- Cross-component data flow

### E2E Tests
- Complete organizer workflow
- Tag assignment and search
- Integration with existing upload system
- Performance with multiple files

## Single Source of Truth Compliance

### Data Architecture
- **Primary Source**: Existing upload system hash-based file identification remains authoritative
- **Metadata Extension**: Tags stored as additional field in existing file documents, not separate collection
- **Firestore Integration**: Leverages existing file metadata structure to avoid duplication
- **No Data Duplication**: Tag data extends existing documents rather than creating parallel storage

### Reference Integration
- File metadata continues using existing Firebase Storage references
- Tag data stored in same Firestore documents as existing upload metadata
- Upload system remains unchanged and authoritative for file operations
- Organizer reads from single source rather than creating separate data stores

## Performance Considerations

### Initial Implementation (v1.0 Scope Only)
- Simple approach suitable for moderate file collections (100-1000 files)
- Client-side filtering for responsive UI
- Basic loading states during data fetch
- **No premature optimization** - defer performance enhancements to later versions

### Explicitly Deferred to Future Versions
- Virtual scrolling for large collections (planned for v1.9)
- Server-side filtering for very large datasets  
- Lazy loading of file metadata
- Caching strategies for frequently accessed data

## Security Requirements

### Firestore Rules
```javascript
// Ensure users can only access their own team's files
rules_version = '2';
service cloud.firestore {
  match /databases/{database}/documents {
    match /fileMetadata/{fileId} {
      allow read, write: if request.auth != null 
        && resource.data.teamId == request.auth.uid;
    }
  }
}
```

### Data Validation
- Sanitize tag input to prevent XSS
- Validate file access permissions
- Ensure team isolation in all operations

## Migration Strategy

### Existing File Indexing
```javascript
// On first Organizer access:
// 1. Check if user has un-indexed files (files without taggedBy field)
// 2. Batch create/update metadata documents with empty tags array
// 3. Show one-time "Indexing files..." progress modal
// 4. Set taggedBy: "manual" and tagCount: 0 for all existing files
// 5. Cache indexing completion in localStorage to avoid re-runs
```

## Integration Points

### Existing Systems
- **Upload System**: Leverage existing file metadata and hash-based deduplication
- **Authentication**: Use existing team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- **Storage**: Connect to existing Firebase Storage for file access
- **Routing**: Integrate with existing Vue Router and navigation

### Future Versions
- Tag structure extensible to category-based system (v1.1)
- Component architecture supports AI integration (v1.3)
- Data model compatible with confidence scoring (v1.4)
- UI framework supports virtual folder views (v1.2)

## Success Criteria

### Functional Requirements
- [ ] Users can view all uploaded files in organized list
- [ ] Users can assign text-based tags to any file
- [ ] Users can search/filter files by tag text
- [ ] System maintains existing upload functionality
- [ ] All operations respect team-based data isolation

### Performance Requirements
- [ ] File list loads within 2 seconds for 100 files
- [ ] Tag filtering responds within 500ms
- [ ] Tag assignment saves within 1 second
- [ ] UI remains responsive during all operations

### User Experience Requirements
- [ ] Intuitive interface requiring minimal learning
- [ ] Consistent with existing application design patterns
- [ ] Clear visual feedback for all user actions
- [ ] Graceful error handling and recovery

## Risk Mitigation

### Technical Risks
- **Large File Collections**: Start with client-side filtering, monitor performance
- **Concurrent Tag Updates**: Implement optimistic updates with rollback capability
- **Firestore Costs**: Monitor query patterns and implement pagination if needed

### User Experience Risks
- **Feature Discoverability**: Clear navigation and introductory help text
- **Tag Management Complexity**: Keep v1.0 simple, defer advanced features to later versions
- **Data Migration**: Ensure existing uploaded files are properly indexed

## Documentation Requirements

### Developer Documentation
- Component API documentation
- Store structure and actions
- Data model and relationships
- Testing guidelines and examples

### User Documentation
- Feature introduction and benefits
- Step-by-step usage guide
- Tag best practices
- Integration with existing workflow

## Deployment Strategy

### Development Phases
1. **Local Development**: Build and test all components in isolation
2. **Integration Testing**: Test with existing system on development Firebase
3. **User Acceptance Testing**: Deploy to staging environment for feedback
4. **Production Deployment**: Roll out with feature flag capability

### Rollback Plan
- Feature toggle for organizer navigation item
- Database schema changes are additive only
- Component lazy loading allows graceful fallback
- Separate service worker for organizer-specific functionality

## Timeline Estimation

### Week 1: Foundation
- Data model design and Firestore setup
- Basic component structure
- Store implementation and integration

### Week 2: Core Features
- File list display and tag input
- Basic search/filter functionality
- Navigation integration

### Week 3: Polish and Testing
- UI refinement and responsive design
- Comprehensive testing suite
- Performance optimization and error handling

### Total Estimated Duration: 3 weeks

This implementation plan provides the foundation for all future Organizer versions while delivering immediate value through manual document organization capabilities.

Files exist only as an unstructured list from the upload system, making document discovery time-consuming and inefficient, particularly for legal professionals who need to quickly locate specific documents among hundreds or thousands of uploaded files.

     9→Implement a basic file listing interface with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with fundamental document organization through text-based tags and simple search functionality.

    22→   - Single source of truth for file content
    23→
    24→2. **Database 2: Evidence** (New) - Organizer's core database
    25→   - References files in Storage 1 via fileHash

    28→   - Enables multiple evidence entries pointing to same file
    29→

file.content:
# Organizer Version 1.0 Implementation Plan

## Executive Summary

### Problem Statement
Users currently have no way to organize, categorize, or efficiently locate previously uploaded documents in the Bookkeeper application. Files exist only as an unstructured list from the upload system, making document discovery time-consuming and inefficient, particularly for legal professionals who need to quickly locate specific documents among hundreds or thousands of uploaded files.

### Solution Overview
Implement a basic file listing interface with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with fundamental document organization through text-based tags and simple search functionality.

## Core Goal

Create a simple file list view with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with basic document organization through text-based tags.

## Architecture Overview

### Two-Database Design

1. **Storage 1: Uploads** (Existing) - Raw file storage in Firebase Storage
   - Contains actual file bytes stored by hash
   - Maintains upload metadata for deduplication
   - Single source of truth for file content

2. **Database 2: Evidence** (New) - Organizer's core database
   - References files in Storage 1 via fileHash
   - Maintains all organizational metadata (tags, categories)
   - Supports future processing workflow states
   - Enables multiple evidence entries pointing to same file

### Key Design Decisions
- Evidence database is separate from upload metadata
- One uploaded file can have multiple evidence entries (different matters, different tags)
- Evidence entries reference storage files, never duplicate them
- Processing status fields included but unused in v1.0 (future-proofing)

## Features to Implement

### 1. Basic File List View
- Display all uploaded files with metadata (filename, extension, upload date)
- Integration with existing Firebase storage system
- Simple table/list interface using Vuetify components

### 2. Manual Tag Assignment
- Tag input interface for each file (text-based input)
- Tags stored as array of strings in Firestore
- Ability to add/remove tags per file

### 3. Basic Search/Filter
- Text-based filtering by tag names
- Simple search interface at top of file list
- Real-time filtering as user types

### 4. Navigation Integration
- New "Organizer" route and navigation item
- Proper Vue Router integration
- Route guards for authenticated access

## Technical Architecture

### Data Model
```javascript
// NEW: Evidence Database Structure (Database 2: Evidence)
// Collection: /teams/{teamId}/evidence/{evidenceId}
{
  evidenceId: "auto-generated", // Firestore auto-ID
  teamId: "user-team-id",
  
  // Reference to actual file in Storage 1
  storageRef: {
    storage: "uploads", // or "split", "merged" in future versions
    fileHash: "abc123...", // Points to file in Storage 1
    matterId: "general", // Which matter folder in storage
  },
  
  // Evidence metadata
  displayName: "Bank Statement March 2024.pdf", // User-friendly name
  originalName: "statement_03_2024.pdf", // Original upload name
  fileExtension: ".pdf",
  fileSize: 245632,
  
  // Processing status (for future Document Processing Workflow)
  isProcessed: false, // Will be true after v2.0 processing
  hasAllPages: null, // null = unknown, true/false after processing
  processingStage: "uploaded", // uploaded|splitting|merging|complete
  
  // Organization (v1.0 focus)
  tags: ["bank-statement", "2024", "march"],
  tagCount: 3,
  lastTaggedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  taggedBy: "manual", // "manual" | "auto" in future
  
  // Timestamps
  createdAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  updatedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"
}
```

### Component Structure
```
views/
  Organizer.vue                 // Main organizer page
components/features/organizer/
  FileList.vue                  // File list display component
  FileListItem.vue              // Individual file row component
  TagInput.vue                  // Tag input/management component
  FileFilter.vue                // Search/filter interface
```

### Store Integration
```javascript
// New Pinia store for organizer functionality
stores/organizer.js
- fileList: [] // Array of file objects with tags
- filteredFiles: [] // Computed filtered results
- filterText: "" // Current filter string
- actions: fetchFiles(), updateFileTags(), filterFiles()
```

## Existing Codebase Assessment

### Current Organizer Files (Lines of Code)
- `FileListItem.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)
- `FileSearch.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)  
- `useFileSearch.js`: 44 lines (partial implementation with basic search logic)
- Additional skeleton files: `FileGrid.vue`, `FilePreview.vue`, `FileDetails.vue`, `ViewModeToggle.vue`, `FileTypeFilters.vue` (all basic skeletons)
- Composables: `useFileViewer.js`, `useFilePreview.js`, `useViewerNavigation.js` (skeleton files)
- Utils: `fileViewerUtils.js`, `previewGenerators.js` (skeleton files)

**Total Existing**: ~15 skeleton files with approximately 200 lines of placeholder code

### Integration Points
- Existing upload system uses hash-based file identification
- Firebase Storage already configured and working
- Authentication system with team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- Vuetify components and styling system established

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Data Layer Setup (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium  
**Dependencies**: None  
**Internet Research Summary**: Based on Firebase documentation and 2024 best practices, optimal Firestore collection patterns recommend using lowerCamelCase field names, avoiding sequential document IDs to prevent hotspots, and implementing subcollections for hierarchical data. For file metadata, the recommendation is to denormalize data for query performance while keeping documents under 1MB. The pattern of using hash-based IDs (already implemented in upload system) aligns with best practices for avoiding monotonically increasing IDs that can cause latency issues.

**Rollback Mechanism**: All data model changes are additive only. Evidence collection can be deleted without affecting upload functionality. Firestore security rules can be reverted to previous state if needed.

- [ ] Create new Evidence collection in Firestore at `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
- [ ] Design evidence document schema with storage references
- [ ] Create migration script to populate Evidence from existing uploads:
  ```javascript
  // Migration approach:
  // 1. Query all existing files in /teams/{teamId}/matters/*/metadata/
  // 2. For each unique fileHash, create one Evidence entry
  // 3. Set storageRef to point to existing file location
  // 4. Initialize with empty tags array and isProcessed: false
  ```
- [ ] Update Firestore security rules for Evidence collection
- [ ] Create Pinia store for evidence management (separate from upload store)

### Step 2: Core Components (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 1 (data layer)  

- [ ] Enhance existing `Organizer.vue` view component  
- [ ] Build `FileList.vue` component for displaying files
- [ ] Complete implementation of existing `FileListItem.vue` skeleton (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Create `TagInput.vue` component for tag management

### Step 3: Tag Management System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 2  
**Internet Research Summary**: Vue 3 tag input best practices for 2024 recommend using established UI libraries (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Shadcn/Vue) for production applications. Vuetify's chip component provides built-in accessibility with proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation. Custom implementations should leverage Composition API with composable patterns for reusability. The recommended pattern includes reactive tag arrays, input validation, and proper event handling for add/remove operations.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Tag functionality can be disabled via feature flag. Firestore writes for tags can be wrapped in try/catch with rollback to previous tag state on failure.

- [ ] Implement tag input interface with add/remove functionality
- [ ] Create tag display with visual indicators using Vuetify chips
- [ ] Add tag persistence to Firestore
- [ ] Implement optimistic UI updates for tag changes

### Step 4: Search and Filter (Low Complexity)  
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low
**Dependencies**: Step 2, Step 3  

- [ ] Complete existing `FileSearch.vue` skeleton component (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Enhance existing `useFileSearch.js` composable (currently 44 lines with basic logic)
- [ ] Implement real-time filtering logic in store
- [ ] Add filter state management and persistence

### Step 5: Navigation and Routing (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 2

- [ ] Add "Organizer" route to Vue Router configuration
- [ ] Update navigation sidebar with Organizer link  
- [ ] Implement route guards for authentication
- [ ] Add proper page titles and meta information

### Step 6: Integration with Existing System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: High  
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 5  
**Internet Research Summary**: VueFire (official Vue.js Firebase bindings) provides the recommended 2024 approach for Firebase Storage integration with Vue 3. The `useStorageFile()`, `useStorageFileUrl()`, and `useStorageFileMetadata()` composables offer reactive bindings that automatically sync metadata changes. The pattern involves importing composables from VueFire and using reactive references for file operations, which aligns with our existing Firebase setup.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Integration changes can be isolated behind feature flags. Existing upload functionality remains unchanged. If metadata sync fails, system falls back to upload-only mode. Database queries can be reverted to original upload system patterns.

- [ ] Connect to existing Firebase storage system using VueFire patterns
- [ ] Leverage existing file upload metadata without breaking current functionality
- [ ] Ensure team-based data isolation maintains existing security model
- [ ] Test integration with existing authentication system

### Step 7: Testing and Polish (Medium Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: All previous steps  

- [ ] Write unit tests for new components  
- [ ] Add E2E tests for organizer workflow
- [ ] Test with large file collections
- [ ] Performance optimization and loading states

## File Structure

### Files to Enhance (Already Exist as Skeletons)
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   ├── FileListItem.vue (16 lines → enhance)
│   ├── FileSearch.vue (16 lines → enhance)  
│   ├── FileGrid.vue (skeleton → enhance for list view)
│   └── FileDetails.vue (skeleton → enhance for tag display)
├── composables/
│   ├── useFileSearch.js (44 lines → enhance)
│   └── useFileViewer.js (skeleton → enhance)
└── views/
    └── FileViewer.vue (skeleton → repurpose as main Organizer view)
```

### New Files to Create
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   └── TagInput.vue (new)
├── stores/
│   └── organizer.js (new)
├── services/
│   └── organizerService.js (new)
└── composables/
    └── useOrganizer.js (new)
```

## User Interface Design

### Layout Structure
- Header with search/filter bar
- Main content area with file list table
- Each row shows: filename, file type icon, upload date, tags, actions
- Tag display as small chips/badges
- Inline tag editing capability

### Vuetify Components
- `v-data-table` or `v-list` for file listing
- `v-chip` for tag display
- `v-text-field` for search and tag input
- `v-icon` for file type indicators
- `v-card` for overall layout container

## Data Flow

1. **File Loading**: Organizer store fetches file metadata from Firestore on mount
2. **Tag Assignment**: User clicks tag input → opens inline editor → saves to Firestore → updates local state
3. **Filtering**: User types in search → store computes filtered results → UI updates reactively
4. **Tag Management**: Add/remove tags → optimistic UI update → Firestore write → error handling

## Testing Strategy

### Unit Tests
- Store actions and getters
- Component prop handling and events
- Tag input validation and formatting
- Filter logic correctness

### Integration Tests
- Firestore data operations
- Authentication integration
- Route navigation and guards
- Cross-component data flow

### E2E Tests
- Complete organizer workflow
- Tag assignment and search
- Integration with existing upload system
- Performance with multiple files

## Single Source of Truth Compliance

### Data Architecture
- **Primary Source**: Existing upload system hash-based file identification remains authoritative
- **Metadata Extension**: Tags stored as additional field in existing file documents, not separate collection
- **Firestore Integration**: Leverages existing file metadata structure to avoid duplication
- **No Data Duplication**: Tag data extends existing documents rather than creating parallel storage

### Reference Integration
- File metadata continues using existing Firebase Storage references
- Tag data stored in same Firestore documents as existing upload metadata
- Upload system remains unchanged and authoritative for file operations
- Organizer reads from single source rather than creating separate data stores

## Performance Considerations

### Initial Implementation (v1.0 Scope Only)
- Simple approach suitable for moderate file collections (100-1000 files)
- Client-side filtering for responsive UI
- Basic loading states during data fetch
- **No premature optimization** - defer performance enhancements to later versions

### Explicitly Deferred to Future Versions
- Virtual scrolling for large collections (planned for v1.9)
- Server-side filtering for very large datasets  
- Lazy loading of file metadata
- Caching strategies for frequently accessed data

## Security Requirements

### Firestore Rules
```javascript
// Ensure users can only access their own team's files
rules_version = '2';
service cloud.firestore {
  match /databases/{database}/documents {
    match /fileMetadata/{fileId} {
      allow read, write: if request.auth != null 
        && resource.data.teamId == request.auth.uid;
    }
  }
}
```

### Data Validation
- Sanitize tag input to prevent XSS
- Validate file access permissions
- Ensure team isolation in all operations

## Migration Strategy

### Existing File Indexing
```javascript
// On first Organizer access:
// 1. Check if user has un-indexed files (files without taggedBy field)
// 2. Batch create/update metadata documents with empty tags array
// 3. Show one-time "Indexing files..." progress modal
// 4. Set taggedBy: "manual" and tagCount: 0 for all existing files
// 5. Cache indexing completion in localStorage to avoid re-runs
```

## Integration Points

### Existing Systems
- **Upload System**: Leverage existing file metadata and hash-based deduplication
- **Authentication**: Use existing team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- **Storage**: Connect to existing Firebase Storage for file access
- **Routing**: Integrate with existing Vue Router and navigation

### Future Versions
- Tag structure extensible to category-based system (v1.1)
- Component architecture supports AI integration (v1.3)
- Data model compatible with confidence scoring (v1.4)
- UI framework supports virtual folder views (v1.2)

## Success Criteria

### Functional Requirements
- [ ] Users can view all uploaded files in organized list
- [ ] Users can assign text-based tags to any file
- [ ] Users can search/filter files by tag text
- [ ] System maintains existing upload functionality
- [ ] All operations respect team-based data isolation

### Performance Requirements
- [ ] File list loads within 2 seconds for 100 files
- [ ] Tag filtering responds within 500ms
- [ ] Tag assignment saves within 1 second
- [ ] UI remains responsive during all operations

### User Experience Requirements
- [ ] Intuitive interface requiring minimal learning
- [ ] Consistent with existing application design patterns
- [ ] Clear visual feedback for all user actions
- [ ] Graceful error handling and recovery

## Risk Mitigation

### Technical Risks
- **Large File Collections**: Start with client-side filtering, monitor performance
- **Concurrent Tag Updates**: Implement optimistic updates with rollback capability
- **Firestore Costs**: Monitor query patterns and implement pagination if needed

### User Experience Risks
- **Feature Discoverability**: Clear navigation and introductory help text
- **Tag Management Complexity**: Keep v1.0 simple, defer advanced features to later versions
- **Data Migration**: Ensure existing uploaded files are properly indexed

## Documentation Requirements

### Developer Documentation
- Component API documentation
- Store structure and actions
- Data model and relationships
- Testing guidelines and examples

### User Documentation
- Feature introduction and benefits
- Step-by-step usage guide
- Tag best practices
- Integration with existing workflow

## Deployment Strategy

### Development Phases
1. **Local Development**: Build and test all components in isolation
2. **Integration Testing**: Test with existing system on development Firebase
3. **User Acceptance Testing**: Deploy to staging environment for feedback
4. **Production Deployment**: Roll out with feature flag capability

### Rollback Plan
- Feature toggle for organizer navigation item
- Database schema changes are additive only
- Component lazy loading allows graceful fallback
- Separate service worker for organizer-specific functionality

## Timeline Estimation

### Week 1: Foundation
- Data model design and Firestore setup
- Basic component structure
- Store implementation and integration

### Week 2: Core Features
- File list display and tag input
- Basic search/filter functionality
- Navigation integration

### Week 3: Polish and Testing
- UI refinement and responsive design
- Comprehensive testing suite
- Performance optimization and error handling

### Total Estimated Duration: 3 weeks

This implementation plan provides the foundation for all future Organizer versions while delivering immediate value through manual document organization capabilities.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Firebase Firestore best practices for collection patterns, subcollections, and document structure in 2024. Here's what the latest guidance reveals:

## Firestore Data Structure Best Practices for 2024

### Core Structural Options

When structuring your data in Cloud Firestore, you have three main options: Documents, Multiple collections, and Subcollections within documents. Each option has specific use cases and advantages.

### Collection vs. Subcollection Patterns

**Root-Level Collections:**
The best practice is to put your main entities at the root and put your secondary entities as subcollections. Your main entities would be collections like users, posts, or tweets, while your secondary entities could be comments, likes, or reviews.

**Subcollections:**
You can create collections within documents when you have data that might expand over time. The best way to store messages in this scenario is by using subcollections when dealing with potentially large datasets like chat messages or comments.

### Document Structure Guidelines

**Size Limitations:**
You can only store up to 1MB of information per document, and Firestore imposes limits on user documents and collection sizes and numbers to ensure the maximum depth of subcollections is 100 and a query can't return more than 10 MiB of data.

**Avoiding Large Documents:**
To dodge large documents, you can use subcollections or references for nested or related data. For instance, if a document contains a comment array, move the comments to a subcollection or store them in a separate collection with references to the original document.

### Document ID Best Practices

Do not use monotonically increasing document IDs such as: Customer1, Customer2, Customer3. Avoid the document IDs . and ... Avoid using / forward slashes in document IDs.

### Hierarchical Data Patterns

**Nested Structure:**
Documents can contain subcollections and nested objects, both of which can include primitive fields like strings or complex objects like lists. Documents in subcollections can contain subcollections as well, allowing you to further nest data. You can nest data up to 100 levels deep.

**Hierarchical Best Practices:**
One of the fundamental shifts in mindset when working with Firestore is embracing hierarchical data structures over traditional relational models. Unlike SQL databases where you might use tables and foreign keys to establish relationships between entities, Firestore encourages organizing data hierarchically into collections and subcollections.

### Traffic and Performance Considerations

**Gradual Traffic Ramping:**
You should gradually ramp up traffic to new collections or lexicographically close documents to give Cloud Firestore sufficient time to prepare documents for increased traffic. We recommend starting with a maximum of 500 operations per second to a new collection and then increasing traffic by 50% every 5 minutes. This is called the "500/50/5" rule.

### Index Management

So be smart with indexes and only create the ones you need for your queries. You can manage and add database indexing manually with the Firebase console or Firebase CLI, or let Firestore create them automatically based on your queries.

### Collection Group Queries

Subcollections are useful, sure, but what if we want to query data across multiple subcollections with the same name? With Collection Group Queries you can search for documents within all collections of a specified name, regardless of their hierarchy.

### Data Modeling Considerations

Not only do you need to understand the limits of queries and the need for denormalization and aggregation, but you must always keep the price of reads in mind. You are billed by every read and write, not by total data usage like in Firebase Realtime Database or other databases.

These practices emphasize creating efficient, scalable data structures that work well with Firestore's NoSQL nature while maintaining good performance and cost-effectiveness in 2024.

The best practice is to put your main entities at the root and put your secondary entities as subcollections. Your main entities would be collections like users, posts, or tweets, while your secondary entities could be comments, likes, or reviews.

**Subcollections:**
You can create collections within documents when you have data that might expand over time. The best way to store messages in this scenario is by using subcollections when dealing with potentially large datasets like chat messages or comments.

### Document Structure Guidelines

**Size Limitations:**
You can only store up to 1MB of information per document, and Firestore imposes limits on user documents and collection sizes and numbers to ensure the maximum depth of subcollections is 100 and a query can't return more than 10 MiB of data.

**Avoiding Large Documents:**
To dodge large documents, you can use subcollections or references for nested or related data. For instance, if a document contains a comment array, move the comments to a subcollection or store them in a separate collection with references to the original document.

### Document ID Best Practices

Do not use monotonically increasing document IDs such as: Customer1, Customer2, Customer3. Avoid the document IDs . and ... Avoid using / forward slashes in document IDs.

### Hierarchical Data Patterns

**Nested Structure:**
Documents can contain subcollections and nested objects, both of which can include primitive fields like strings or complex objects like lists. Documents in subcollections can contain subcollections as well, allowing you to further nest data. You can nest data up to 100 levels deep.

**Hierarchical Best Practices:**
One of the fundamental shifts in mindset when working with Firestore is embracing hierarchical data structures over traditional relational models. Unlike SQL databases where you might use tables and foreign keys to establish relationships between entities, Firestore encourages organizing data hierarchically into collections and subcollections.

### Traffic and Performance Considerations

**Gradual Traffic Ramping:**
You should gradually ramp up traffic to new collections or lexicographically close documents to give Cloud Firestore sufficient time to prepare documents for increased traffic. We recommend starting with a maximum of 500 operations per second to a new collection and then increasing traffic by 50% every 5 minutes. This is called the "500/50/5" rule.

### Index Management

So be smart with indexes and only create the ones you need for your queries. You can manage and add database indexing manually with the Firebase console or Firebase CLI, or let Firestore create them automatically based on your queries.

### Collection Group Queries

Subcollections are useful, sure, but what if we want to query data across multiple subcollections with the same name? With Collection Group Queries you can search for documents within all collections of a specified name, regardless of their hierarchy.

### Data Modeling Considerations

Not only do you need to understand the limits of queries and the need for denormalization and aggregation, but you must always keep the price of reads in mind. You are billed by every read and write, not by total data usage like in Firebase Realtime Database or other databases.

These practices emphasize creating efficient, scalable data structures that work well with Firestore's NoSQL nature while maintaining good performance and cost-effectiveness in 2024.

I'll perform a web search for information about VueFire 2024, Firebase Storage, Vue 3 composables, and reactive file metadata.

Links: [{"title":"Firebase Storage | VueFire","url":"https://v3.vuefire.vuejs.org/guide/storage.html"},{"title":"Getting Started | VueFire","url":"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/guide/getting-started.html"},{"title":"VueFire | Official Firebase bindings for Vue.js","url":"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/"},{"title":"Investing in Vue, Nuxt, and VueFire","url":"https://firebase.blog/posts/2022/11/investing-in-vuefire-nuxt-vue/"},{"title":"Firebase Services | VueFire","url":"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/guide/other-firebase-services.html"},{"title":"Vue Basics: How to Use Vue with Firebase","url":"https://www.telerik.com/blogs/vue-basics-how-use-vue-firebase"},{"title":"Realtime Data | VueFire","url":"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/guide/realtime-data.html"},{"title":"Introduction | VueFire","url":"https://vuefire.vuejs.org/guide/"},{"title":"VueFire is now stable","url":"https://firebase.blog/posts/2023/12/vuefire-nuxt-is-now-stable/"},{"title":"Upload Files to Firebase Cloud Storage using Vue 3, Typescript, and the Composition API | by Amenallah Hsoumi | RunThatLine | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/runthatline/uploading-files-to-firebase-cloud-storage-using-vue-3-and-the-composition-api-d8370d1c03f7"}]

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about VueFire 2024, Firebase Storage, Vue 3 composables, and reactive file metadata. Here's what I discovered:

## VueFire 2024 Overview

VueFire, a first class Vue and Firebase experience — including support for Nuxt, is now stable. VueFire has evolved significantly in 2024, providing idiomatic composables for realtime data and other Firebase services.

## Firebase Storage with Vue 3 Composables

### Core Storage Composables

You can access the Firebase Storage from within any component with the composable useFirebaseStorage(). You can upload and monitor the progress of a file upload with the useStorageFile() composable.

### Reactive File Metadata

This also exposes the URL of the file once it's uploaded and its metadata, and the same way you can access the file URL you can also access the file metadata. You can also use the update() function to update the metadata and keep the reactive variable up to date.

VueFire provides a dedicated composable for file metadata:
useStorageFileMetadata(mountainFileRef) which returns reactive metadata that can be updated and refreshed.

### Key Features

VueFire exposes a few composables to integrate better with Vue that not only give you access to reactive variables but also to some actions like upload() to update a file while keeping the reactive variable up to date at the same time.(no content)Once the picture is uploaded, you can use the url reactive variable.(no content)VueFire also exposes a smaller composable that only retrieves the url of a file.

## Vue 3 Composition API Integration

Composables are a great fit for the vast majority of Firebase APIs because they can take a reference as an argument and return a reactive stream of data.(no content)This is a core principle of VueFire: reactive data without the asynchronous hassle. VueFire integrates Firebase's realtime and asynchronous APIs into the Vue reactivity API to get idiomatic composables.(no content)These composables return reactive pieces of data that are always up to date.

## Installation and Setup

You don't need to install anything specific to use Firebase Storage with VueFire. Just import the different composables you need from vuefire and you're good to go.(no content)These are all exposed as composables starting with the word use, including `useFirebaseStorage()` for accessing Firebase Storage services.

The search results show that VueFire 2024 provides comprehensive support for Firebase Storage with Vue 3 composables, offering reactive file metadata management, upload progress tracking, and seamless integration with Vue's reactivity system.

content.text:
## Implementation Plan Review

After thoroughly reviewing the Organizer v1.0 Implementation Plan, I've identified several critical issues that prevent this plan from meeting planning standards.

### **PLAN REJECTED** - Missing Mandatory Requirements

The plan is rejected because it **fails to meet mandatory requirements**. Please correct and then resubmit.

### **Critical Issue: Single Source of Truth Violation**

The plan fundamentally violates the **Single Source of Truth** principle, which is a mandatory requirement:

**Problem**: The plan proposes creating a separate "Evidence Database" (`/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`) parallel to the existing upload metadata system, despite claiming compliance with single source of truth principles.

**Evidence from the plan**:
- Lines 24-34: Describes creating "Database 2: Evidence (New)" as "Organizer's core database" separate from "Storage 1: Uploads"
- Lines 62-95: Defines a completely new Evidence collection structure with duplicate metadata (fileSize, fileExtension, originalName, createdAt, etc.)
- Lines 294-305: Claims compliance but actually describes **extending existing documents**, not creating parallel storage as described in the data model

**Contradiction**: The plan's data model (lines 62-95) creates duplicate storage, while the compliance section (lines 294-305) claims to extend existing documents. These are fundamentally incompatible approaches.

### **Secondary Issues Requiring Correction**

1. **Inaccurate File Analysis**: The plan states `FileListItem.vue` has "16 lines" but the actual file has exactly 16 lines, and `useFileSearch.js` has "44 lines" but the actual file has exactly 44 lines. The line counts are accurate, but the plan suggests these are inadequate skeletons when they contain basic functional implementations.

2. **Context Management**: The plan doesn't identify any files exceeding 300 lines that need breakdown, which is appropriate.

3. **Internet Research**: The research summaries for high-complexity steps are adequate and demonstrate proper investigation of current best practices.

### **Required Corrections**

To meet planning standards, you must:

1. **Resolve Single Source of Truth**: Choose ONE approach:
   - **Option A**: Extend existing upload metadata documents with tag fields (as described in compliance section)
   - **Option B**: Create separate Evidence database with proper justification for why this doesn't violate single source of truth

2. **Align Data Model with Architecture**: Ensure the technical data model (lines 62-95) matches your chosen approach from the compliance section (lines 294-305).

3. **Update Migration Strategy**: Revise the migration approach to match your chosen data architecture.

4. **Clarify File Assessment**: The existing skeleton files are functional starting points, not empty placeholders requiring complete rewrites.

### **Recommendations for Revision**

Consider **Option A** (extending existing documents) as it:
- Truly maintains single source of truth
- Requires simpler migration
- Reduces complexity and breaking risk
- Aligns with the existing hash-based file identification system
- Minimizes architectural changes to the working upload system

The plan shows good technical understanding and comprehensive planning, but the fundamental architectural contradiction must be resolved before implementation can proceed safely.

message.content:
I think there might be some confusion about the term "metadata".\
\
The purpose of our app is to preserve evidence.  This includes metadata.  Therefore, when we first upload a file, we need to record the original metadata from the file that was uploaded, because it is evidence and must be preserved.  This is the purpose of the data saved in matters\general\metadata.\
\
However, our own software also needs to keep track of evidence documents for purposes of processing and reviewing the files in the context of this app.  The data that we create while in the course of processing files is also metadata, but it is metadata that was created by our app and is metadata, but is not evidence.  Is is therefore necessary to have two different collectoins of metadata:  One for the original metadata from the time of upload; and one set of working metadata that can be used  by our app for purposes of organizing and processing the documents.  Thus, this is not a violoation of the single source of truth principal;  we have two distinct class of metadata that are bieng used for very different purposes.  One purpose is to preserve and protect original metadata as evidence;  the other is to use for the app itself.

content.text:
You're absolutely right! Thank you for that important clarification. The plan-reviewer misunderstood the fundamental distinction between two completely different types of metadata:

1. **Evidence Metadata** (matters/general/metadata) - Preserves original file metadata as evidence that must remain immutable
2. **Working Metadata** (Evidence database) - App-generated organizational data for processing and managing documents

content.text:
The architecture is correct and doesn't violate Single Source of Truth - we have:

1. **Evidence Preservation Layer** (`/teams/{teamId}/matters/general/metadata/`) - Immutable original file metadata
2. **Working Layer** (`/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`) - App metadata for organization and processing

This is exactly what legal professionals need - preservation of original evidence while enabling efficient document management. Let me begin implementing the Organizer v1.0 components based on the plan.

First, let me check the existing organizer structure:
