   118→
   119→## Existing Codebase Assessment
   120→
   121→### Current Organizer Files (Lines of Code)
   122→- `FileListItem.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)
   123→- `FileSearch.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)  
   124→- `useFileSearch.js`: 44 lines (partial implementation with basic search logic)
   125→- Additional skeleton files: `FileGrid.vue`, `FilePreview.vue`, `FileDetails.vue`, `ViewModeToggle.vue`, `FileTypeFilters.vue` (all basic skeletons)
   126→- Composables: `useFileViewer.js`, `useFilePreview.js`, `useViewerNavigation.js` (skeleton files)
   127→- Utils: `fileViewerUtils.js`, `previewGenerators.js` (skeleton files)
   128→
   129→**Total Existing**: ~15 skeleton files with approximately 200 lines of placeholder code
   130→
   131→### Integration Points
   132→- Existing upload system uses hash-based file identification
   133→- Firebase Storage already configured and working
   134→- Authentication system with team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
   135→- Vuetify components and styling system established
   136→
   137→## Implementation Steps
   138→
   139→### Step 1: Data Layer Setup (High Complexity)
   140→**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium  
   141→**Dependencies**: None  
   142→**Internet Research Summary**: Based on Firebase documentation and 2024 best practices, optimal Firestore collection patterns recommend using lowerCamelCase field names, avoiding sequential document IDs to prevent hotspots, and implementing subcollections for hierarchical data. For file metadata, the recommendation is to denormalize data for query performance while keeping documents under 1MB. The pattern of using hash-based IDs (already implemented in upload system) aligns with best practices for avoiding monotonically increasing IDs that can cause latency issues.
   143→
   144→**Rollback Mechanism**: All data model changes are additive only. Evidence collection can be deleted without affecting upload functionality. Firestore security rules can be reverted to previous state if needed.
   145→
   146→- [ ] Create new Evidence collection in Firestore at `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
   147→- [ ] Design evidence document schema with storage references
   148→- [ ] Create migration script to populate Evidence from existing uploads:
   149→  ```javascript
   150→  // Migration approach:
   151→  // 1. Query all existing files in /teams/{teamId}/matters/*/metadata/
   152→  // 2. For each unique fileHash, create one Evidence entry
   153→  // 3. Set storageRef to point to existing file location
   154→  // 4. Initialize with empty tags array and isProcessed: false
   155→  ```
   156→- [ ] Update Firestore security rules for Evidence collection
   157→- [ ] Create Pinia store for evidence management (separate from upload store)
   158→
   159→### Step 2: Core Components (Low Complexity)
   160→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   161→**Dependencies**: Step 1 (data layer)  
   162→
   163→- [ ] Enhance existing `Organizer.vue` view component  
   164→- [ ] Build `FileList.vue` component for displaying files
   165→- [ ] Complete implementation of existing `FileListItem.vue` skeleton (currently 16 lines)
   166→- [ ] Create `TagInput.vue` component for tag management
   167→
   168→### Step 3: Tag Management System (High Complexity)
   169→**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium
   170→**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 2  
   171→**Internet Research Summary**: Vue 3 tag input best practices for 2024 recommend using established UI libraries (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Shadcn/Vue) for production applications. Vuetify's chip component provides built-in accessibility with proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation. Custom implementations should leverage Composition API with composable patterns for reusability. The recommended pattern includes reactive tag arrays, input validation, and proper event handling for add/remove operations.
   172→
   173→**Rollback Mechanism**: Tag functionality can be disabled via feature flag. Firestore writes for tags can be wrapped in try/catch with rollback to previous tag state on failure.
   174→
   175→- [ ] Implement tag input interface with add/remove functionality
   176→- [ ] Create tag display with visual indicators using Vuetify chips
   177→- [ ] Add tag persistence to Firestore
   178→- [ ] Implement optimistic UI updates for tag changes
   179→
   180→### Step 4: Search and Filter (Low Complexity)  
   181→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low
   182→**Dependencies**: Step 2, Step 3  
   183→
   184→- [ ] Complete existing `FileSearch.vue` skeleton component (currently 16 lines)
   185→- [ ] Enhance existing `useFileSearch.js` composable (currently 44 lines with basic logic)
   186→- [ ] Implement real-time filtering logic in store
   187→- [ ] Add filter state management and persistence
   188→
   189→### Step 5: Navigation and Routing (Low Complexity)
   190→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   191→**Dependencies**: Step 2
   192→
   193→- [ ] Add "Organizer" route to Vue Router configuration
   194→- [ ] Update navigation sidebar with Organizer link  
   195→- [ ] Implement route guards for authentication
   196→- [ ] Add proper page titles and meta information
   197→
   198→### Step 6: Integration with Existing System (High Complexity)
   199→**Breaking Risk Level**: High  
   200→**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 5  
   201→**Internet Research Summary**: VueFire (official Vue.js Firebase bindings) provides the recommended 2024 approach for Firebase Storage integration with Vue 3. The `useStorageFile()`, `useStorageFileUrl()`, and `useStorageFileMetadata()` composables offer reactive bindings that automatically sync metadata changes. The pattern involves importing composables from VueFire and using reactive references for file operations, which aligns with our existing Firebase setup.
   202→
   203→**Rollback Mechanism**: Integration changes can be isolated behind feature flags. Existing upload functionality remains unchanged. If metadata sync fails, system falls back to upload-only mode. Database queries can be reverted to original upload system patterns.
   204→
   205→- [ ] Connect to existing Firebase storage system using VueFire patterns
   206→- [ ] Leverage existing file upload metadata without breaking current functionality
   207→- [ ] Ensure team-based data isolation maintains existing security model
   208→- [ ] Test integration with existing authentication system
   209→
   210→### Step 7: Testing and Polish (Medium Complexity)
   211→**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
   212→**Dependencies**: All previous steps  
   213→
   214→- [ ] Write unit tests for new components  
   215→- [ ] Add E2E tests for organizer workflow
   216→- [ ] Test with large file collections
   217→- [ ] Performance optimization and loading states
   218→
   219→## File Structure
   220→
   221→### Files to Enhance (Already Exist as Skeletons)
   222→```
   223→src/features/organizer/
   224→├── components/
   225→│   ├── FileListItem.vue (16 lines → enhance)
   226→│   ├── FileSearch.vue (16 lines → enhance)  
   227→│   ├── FileGrid.vue (skeleton → enhance for list view)
   228→│   └── FileDetails.vue (skeleton → enhance for tag display)
   229→├── composables/
   230→│   ├── useFileSearch.js (44 lines → enhance)
   231→│   └── useFileViewer.js (skeleton → enhance)
   232→└── views/
   233→    └── FileViewer.vue (skeleton → repurpose as main Organizer view)
   234→```
   235→
   236→### New Files to Create
   237→```
   238→src/features/organizer/
   239→├── components/
   240→│   └── TagInput.vue (new)
   241→├── stores/
   242→│   └── organizer.js (new)
   243→├── services/
   244→│   └── organizerService.js (new)
   245→└── composables/
   246→    └── useOrganizer.js (new)
   247→```
   248→
   249→## User Interface Design
   250→
   251→### Layout Structure
   252→- Header with search/filter bar
   253→- Main content area with file list table
   254→- Each row shows: filename, file type icon, upload date, tags, actions
   255→- Tag display as small chips/badges
   256→- Inline tag editing capability
   257→
   258→### Vuetify Components
   259→- `v-data-table` or `v-list` for file listing
   260→- `v-chip` for tag display
   261→- `v-text-field` for search and tag input
   262→- `v-icon` for file type indicators
   263→- `v-card` for overall layout container
   264→
   265→## Data Flow
   266→
   267→1. **File Loading**: Organizer store fetches file metadata from Firestore on mount
   268→2. **Tag Assignment**: User clicks tag input → opens inline editor → saves to Firestore → updates local state
   269→3. **Filtering**: User types in search → store computes filtered results → UI updates reactively
   270→4. **Tag Management**: Add/remove tags → optimistic UI update → Firestore write → error handling
   271→
   272→## Testing Strategy
   273→
   274→### Unit Tests
   275→- Store actions and getters
   276→- Component prop handling and events
   277→- Tag input validation and formatting
   278→- Filter logic correctness
   279→
   280→### Integration Tests
   281→- Firestore data operations
   282→- Authentication integration
   283→- Route navigation and guards
   284→- Cross-component data flow
   285→
   286→### E2E Tests
   287→- Complete organizer workflow
   288→- Tag assignment and search
   289→- Integration with existing upload system
   290→- Performance with multiple files
   291→
   292→## Single Source of Truth Compliance
   293→
   294→### Data Architecture
   295→- **Primary Source**: Existing upload system hash-based file identification remains authoritative
   296→- **Metadata Extension**: Tags stored as additional field in existing file documents, not separate collection
   297→- **Firestore Integration**: Leverages existing file metadata structure to avoid duplication
   298→- **No Data Duplication**: Tag data extends existing documents rather than creating parallel storage
   299→
   300→### Reference Integration
   301→- File metadata continues using existing Firebase Storage references
   302→- Tag data stored in same Firestore documents as existing upload metadata
   303→- Upload system remains unchanged and authoritative for file operations
   304→- Organizer reads from single source rather than creating separate data stores
   305→
   306→## Performance Considerations
   307→
   308→### Initial Implementation (v1.0 Scope Only)
   309→- Simple approach suitable for moderate file collections (100-1000 files)
   310→- Client-side filtering for responsive UI
   311→- Basic loading states during data fetch
   312→- **No premature optimization** - defer performance enhancements to later versions
   313→
   314→### Explicitly Deferred to Future Versions
   315→- Virtual scrolling for large collections (planned for v1.9)
   316→- Server-side filtering for very large datasets  
   317→- Lazy loading of file metadata
   318→- Caching strategies for frequently accessed data
   319→
   320→## Security Requirements
   321→
   322→### Firestore Rules
   323→```javascript
   324→// Ensure users can only access their own team's files
   325→rules_version = '2';
   326→service cloud.firestore {
   327→  match /databases/{database}/documents {
   328→    match /fileMetadata/{fileId} {
   329→      allow read, write: if request.auth != null 
   330→        && resource.data.teamId == request.auth.uid;
   331→    }
   332→  }
   333→}
   334→```
   335→
   336→### Data Validation
   337→- Sanitize tag input to prevent XSS
   338→- Validate file access permissions
   339→- Ensure team isolation in all operations
   340→
   341→## Migration Strategy
   342→
   343→### Existing File Indexing
   344→```javascript
   345→// On first Organizer access:
   346→// 1. Check if user has un-indexed files (files without taggedBy field)
   347→// 2. Batch create/update metadata documents with empty tags array
   348→// 3. Show one-time "Indexing files..." progress modal
   349→// 4. Set taggedBy: "manual" and tagCount: 0 for all existing files
   350→// 5. Cache indexing completion in localStorage to avoid re-runs
   351→```
   352→
   353→## Integration Points
   354→
   355→### Existing Systems
   356→- **Upload System**: Leverage existing file metadata and hash-based deduplication
   357→- **Authentication**: Use existing team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
   358→- **Storage**: Connect to existing Firebase Storage for file access
   359→- **Routing**: Integrate with existing Vue Router and navigation
   360→
   361→### Future Versions
   362→- Tag structure extensible to category-based system (v1.1)
   363→- Component architecture supports AI integration (v1.3)
   364→- Data model compatible with confidence scoring (v1.4)
   365→- UI framework supports virtual folder views (v1.2)
   366→
   367→## Success Criteria
   368→
   369→### Functional Requirements
   370→- [ ] Users can view all uploaded files in organized list
   371→- [ ] Users can assign text-based tags to any file
   372→- [ ] Users can search/filter files by tag text
   373→- [ ] System maintains existing upload functionality
   374→- [ ] All operations respect team-based data isolation
   375→
   376→### Performance Requirements
   377→- [ ] File list loads within 2 seconds for 100 files
   378→- [ ] Tag filtering responds within 500ms
   379→- [ ] Tag assignment saves within 1 second
   380→- [ ] UI remains responsive during all operations
   381→
   382→### User Experience Requirements
   383→- [ ] Intuitive interface requiring minimal learning
   384→- [ ] Consistent with existing application design patterns
   385→- [ ] Clear visual feedback for all user actions
   386→- [ ] Graceful error handling and recovery
   387→
   388→## Risk Mitigation
   389→
   390→### Technical Risks
   391→- **Large File Collections**: Start with client-side filtering, monitor performance
   392→- **Concurrent Tag Updates**: Implement optimistic updates with rollback capability
   393→- **Firestore Costs**: Monitor query patterns and implement pagination if needed
   394→
   395→### User Experience Risks
   396→- **Feature Discoverability**: Clear navigation and introductory help text
   397→- **Tag Management Complexity**: Keep v1.0 simple, defer advanced features to later versions
   398→- **Data Migration**: Ensure existing uploaded files are properly indexed
   399→
   400→## Documentation Requirements
   401→
   402→### Developer Documentation
   403→- Component API documentation
   404→- Store structure and actions
   405→- Data model and relationships
   406→- Testing guidelines and examples
   407→
   408→### User Documentation
   409→- Feature introduction and benefits
   410→- Step-by-step usage guide
   411→- Tag best practices
   412→- Integration with existing workflow
   413→
   414→## Deployment Strategy
   415→
   416→### Development Phases
   417→1. **Local Development**: Build and test all components in isolation
   418→2. **Integration Testing**: Test with existing system on development Firebase
   419→3. **User Acceptance Testing**: Deploy to staging environment for feedback
   420→4. **Production Deployment**: Roll out with feature flag capability
   421→
   422→### Rollback Plan
   423→- Feature toggle for organizer navigation item
   424→- Database schema changes are additive only
   425→- Component lazy loading allows graceful fallback
   426→- Separate service worker for organizer-specific functionality
   427→
   428→## Timeline Estimation
   429→
   430→### Week 1: Foundation
   431→- Data model design and Firestore setup
   432→- Basic component structure
   433→- Store implementation and integration
   434→
   435→### Week 2: Core Features
   436→- File list display and tag input
   437→- Basic search/filter functionality
   438→- Navigation integration
   439→
   440→### Week 3: Polish and Testing
   441→- UI refinement and responsive design
   442→- Comprehensive testing suite

   444→
   445→### Total Estimated Duration: 3 weeks
   446→
   447→This implementation plan provides the foundation for all future Organizer versions while delivering immediate value through manual document organization capabilities.

file.content:
# Organizer Version 1.0 Implementation Plan

## Executive Summary

### Problem Statement
Users currently have no way to organize, categorize, or efficiently locate previously uploaded documents in the Bookkeeper application. Files exist only as an unstructured list from the upload system, making document discovery time-consuming and inefficient, particularly for legal professionals who need to quickly locate specific documents among hundreds or thousands of uploaded files.

### Solution Overview
Implement a basic file listing interface with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with fundamental document organization through text-based tags and simple search functionality.

## Core Goal

Create a simple file list view with manual tag assignment capability, providing users with basic document organization through text-based tags.

## Architecture Overview

### Two-Database Design

1. **Storage 1: Uploads** (Existing) - Raw file storage in Firebase Storage
   - Contains actual file bytes stored by hash
   - Maintains upload metadata for deduplication
   - Single source of truth for file content

2. **Database 2: Evidence** (New) - Organizer's core database
   - References files in Storage 1 via fileHash
   - Maintains all organizational metadata (tags, categories)
   - Supports future processing workflow states
   - Enables multiple evidence entries pointing to same file

### Key Design Decisions
- Evidence database is separate from upload metadata
- One uploaded file can have multiple evidence entries (different matters, different tags)
- Evidence entries reference storage files, never duplicate them
- Processing status fields included but unused in v1.0 (future-proofing)

## Features to Implement

### 1. Basic File List View
- Display all uploaded files with metadata (filename, extension, upload date)
- Integration with existing Firebase storage system
- Simple table/list interface using Vuetify components

### 2. Manual Tag Assignment
- Tag input interface for each file (text-based input)
- Tags stored as array of strings in Firestore
- Ability to add/remove tags per file

### 3. Basic Search/Filter
- Text-based filtering by tag names
- Simple search interface at top of file list
- Real-time filtering as user types

### 4. Navigation Integration
- New "Organizer" route and navigation item
- Proper Vue Router integration
- Route guards for authenticated access

## Technical Architecture

### Data Model
```javascript
// NEW: Evidence Database Structure (Database 2: Evidence)
// Collection: /teams/{teamId}/evidence/{evidenceId}
{
  evidenceId: "auto-generated", // Firestore auto-ID
  teamId: "user-team-id",
  
  // Reference to actual file in Storage 1
  storageRef: {
    storage: "uploads", // or "split", "merged" in future versions
    fileHash: "abc123...", // Points to file in Storage 1
    matterId: "general", // Which matter folder in storage
  },
  
  // Evidence metadata
  displayName: "Bank Statement March 2024.pdf", // User-friendly name
  originalName: "statement_03_2024.pdf", // Original upload name
  fileExtension: ".pdf",
  fileSize: 245632,
  
  // Processing status (for future Document Processing Workflow)
  isProcessed: false, // Will be true after v2.0 processing
  hasAllPages: null, // null = unknown, true/false after processing
  processingStage: "uploaded", // uploaded|splitting|merging|complete
  
  // Organization (v1.0 focus)
  tags: ["bank-statement", "2024", "march"],
  tagCount: 3,
  lastTaggedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  taggedBy: "manual", // "manual" | "auto" in future
  
  // Timestamps
  createdAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
  updatedAt: "2024-01-01T00:00:00.000Z"
}
```

### Component Structure
```
views/
  Organizer.vue                 // Main organizer page
components/features/organizer/
  FileList.vue                  // File list display component
  FileListItem.vue              // Individual file row component
  TagInput.vue                  // Tag input/management component
  FileFilter.vue                // Search/filter interface
```

### Store Integration
```javascript
// New Pinia store for organizer functionality
stores/organizer.js
- fileList: [] // Array of file objects with tags
- filteredFiles: [] // Computed filtered results
- filterText: "" // Current filter string
- actions: fetchFiles(), updateFileTags(), filterFiles()
```

## Existing Codebase Assessment

### Current Organizer Files (Lines of Code)
- `FileListItem.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)
- `FileSearch.vue`: 16 lines (skeleton with TODO comments)  
- `useFileSearch.js`: 44 lines (partial implementation with basic search logic)
- Additional skeleton files: `FileGrid.vue`, `FilePreview.vue`, `FileDetails.vue`, `ViewModeToggle.vue`, `FileTypeFilters.vue` (all basic skeletons)
- Composables: `useFileViewer.js`, `useFilePreview.js`, `useViewerNavigation.js` (skeleton files)
- Utils: `fileViewerUtils.js`, `previewGenerators.js` (skeleton files)

**Total Existing**: ~15 skeleton files with approximately 200 lines of placeholder code

### Integration Points
- Existing upload system uses hash-based file identification
- Firebase Storage already configured and working
- Authentication system with team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- Vuetify components and styling system established

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Data Layer Setup (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium  
**Dependencies**: None  
**Internet Research Summary**: Based on Firebase documentation and 2024 best practices, optimal Firestore collection patterns recommend using lowerCamelCase field names, avoiding sequential document IDs to prevent hotspots, and implementing subcollections for hierarchical data. For file metadata, the recommendation is to denormalize data for query performance while keeping documents under 1MB. The pattern of using hash-based IDs (already implemented in upload system) aligns with best practices for avoiding monotonically increasing IDs that can cause latency issues.

**Rollback Mechanism**: All data model changes are additive only. Evidence collection can be deleted without affecting upload functionality. Firestore security rules can be reverted to previous state if needed.

- [ ] Create new Evidence collection in Firestore at `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
- [ ] Design evidence document schema with storage references
- [ ] Create migration script to populate Evidence from existing uploads:
  ```javascript
  // Migration approach:
  // 1. Query all existing files in /teams/{teamId}/matters/*/metadata/
  // 2. For each unique fileHash, create one Evidence entry
  // 3. Set storageRef to point to existing file location
  // 4. Initialize with empty tags array and isProcessed: false
  ```
- [ ] Update Firestore security rules for Evidence collection
- [ ] Create Pinia store for evidence management (separate from upload store)

### Step 2: Core Components (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 1 (data layer)  

- [ ] Enhance existing `Organizer.vue` view component  
- [ ] Build `FileList.vue` component for displaying files
- [ ] Complete implementation of existing `FileListItem.vue` skeleton (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Create `TagInput.vue` component for tag management

### Step 3: Tag Management System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Medium
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 2  
**Internet Research Summary**: Vue 3 tag input best practices for 2024 recommend using established UI libraries (PrimeVue, Vuetify, Shadcn/Vue) for production applications. Vuetify's chip component provides built-in accessibility with proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation. Custom implementations should leverage Composition API with composable patterns for reusability. The recommended pattern includes reactive tag arrays, input validation, and proper event handling for add/remove operations.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Tag functionality can be disabled via feature flag. Firestore writes for tags can be wrapped in try/catch with rollback to previous tag state on failure.

- [ ] Implement tag input interface with add/remove functionality
- [ ] Create tag display with visual indicators using Vuetify chips
- [ ] Add tag persistence to Firestore
- [ ] Implement optimistic UI updates for tag changes

### Step 4: Search and Filter (Low Complexity)  
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low
**Dependencies**: Step 2, Step 3  

- [ ] Complete existing `FileSearch.vue` skeleton component (currently 16 lines)
- [ ] Enhance existing `useFileSearch.js` composable (currently 44 lines with basic logic)
- [ ] Implement real-time filtering logic in store
- [ ] Add filter state management and persistence

### Step 5: Navigation and Routing (Low Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: Step 2

- [ ] Add "Organizer" route to Vue Router configuration
- [ ] Update navigation sidebar with Organizer link  
- [ ] Implement route guards for authentication
- [ ] Add proper page titles and meta information

### Step 6: Integration with Existing System (High Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: High  
**Dependencies**: Step 1, Step 5  
**Internet Research Summary**: VueFire (official Vue.js Firebase bindings) provides the recommended 2024 approach for Firebase Storage integration with Vue 3. The `useStorageFile()`, `useStorageFileUrl()`, and `useStorageFileMetadata()` composables offer reactive bindings that automatically sync metadata changes. The pattern involves importing composables from VueFire and using reactive references for file operations, which aligns with our existing Firebase setup.

**Rollback Mechanism**: Integration changes can be isolated behind feature flags. Existing upload functionality remains unchanged. If metadata sync fails, system falls back to upload-only mode. Database queries can be reverted to original upload system patterns.

- [ ] Connect to existing Firebase storage system using VueFire patterns
- [ ] Leverage existing file upload metadata without breaking current functionality
- [ ] Ensure team-based data isolation maintains existing security model
- [ ] Test integration with existing authentication system

### Step 7: Testing and Polish (Medium Complexity)
**Breaking Risk Level**: Low  
**Dependencies**: All previous steps  

- [ ] Write unit tests for new components  
- [ ] Add E2E tests for organizer workflow
- [ ] Test with large file collections
- [ ] Performance optimization and loading states

## File Structure

### Files to Enhance (Already Exist as Skeletons)
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   ├── FileListItem.vue (16 lines → enhance)
│   ├── FileSearch.vue (16 lines → enhance)  
│   ├── FileGrid.vue (skeleton → enhance for list view)
│   └── FileDetails.vue (skeleton → enhance for tag display)
├── composables/
│   ├── useFileSearch.js (44 lines → enhance)
│   └── useFileViewer.js (skeleton → enhance)
└── views/
    └── FileViewer.vue (skeleton → repurpose as main Organizer view)
```

### New Files to Create
```
src/features/organizer/
├── components/
│   └── TagInput.vue (new)
├── stores/
│   └── organizer.js (new)
├── services/
│   └── organizerService.js (new)
└── composables/
    └── useOrganizer.js (new)
```

## User Interface Design

### Layout Structure
- Header with search/filter bar
- Main content area with file list table
- Each row shows: filename, file type icon, upload date, tags, actions
- Tag display as small chips/badges
- Inline tag editing capability

### Vuetify Components
- `v-data-table` or `v-list` for file listing
- `v-chip` for tag display
- `v-text-field` for search and tag input
- `v-icon` for file type indicators
- `v-card` for overall layout container

## Data Flow

1. **File Loading**: Organizer store fetches file metadata from Firestore on mount
2. **Tag Assignment**: User clicks tag input → opens inline editor → saves to Firestore → updates local state
3. **Filtering**: User types in search → store computes filtered results → UI updates reactively
4. **Tag Management**: Add/remove tags → optimistic UI update → Firestore write → error handling

## Testing Strategy

### Unit Tests
- Store actions and getters
- Component prop handling and events
- Tag input validation and formatting
- Filter logic correctness

### Integration Tests
- Firestore data operations
- Authentication integration
- Route navigation and guards
- Cross-component data flow

### E2E Tests
- Complete organizer workflow
- Tag assignment and search
- Integration with existing upload system
- Performance with multiple files

## Single Source of Truth Compliance

### Data Architecture
- **Primary Source**: Existing upload system hash-based file identification remains authoritative
- **Metadata Extension**: Tags stored as additional field in existing file documents, not separate collection
- **Firestore Integration**: Leverages existing file metadata structure to avoid duplication
- **No Data Duplication**: Tag data extends existing documents rather than creating parallel storage

### Reference Integration
- File metadata continues using existing Firebase Storage references
- Tag data stored in same Firestore documents as existing upload metadata
- Upload system remains unchanged and authoritative for file operations
- Organizer reads from single source rather than creating separate data stores

## Performance Considerations

### Initial Implementation (v1.0 Scope Only)
- Simple approach suitable for moderate file collections (100-1000 files)
- Client-side filtering for responsive UI
- Basic loading states during data fetch
- **No premature optimization** - defer performance enhancements to later versions

### Explicitly Deferred to Future Versions
- Virtual scrolling for large collections (planned for v1.9)
- Server-side filtering for very large datasets  
- Lazy loading of file metadata
- Caching strategies for frequently accessed data

## Security Requirements

### Firestore Rules
```javascript
// Ensure users can only access their own team's files
rules_version = '2';
service cloud.firestore {
  match /databases/{database}/documents {
    match /fileMetadata/{fileId} {
      allow read, write: if request.auth != null 
        && resource.data.teamId == request.auth.uid;
    }
  }
}
```

### Data Validation
- Sanitize tag input to prevent XSS
- Validate file access permissions
- Ensure team isolation in all operations

## Migration Strategy

### Existing File Indexing
```javascript
// On first Organizer access:
// 1. Check if user has un-indexed files (files without taggedBy field)
// 2. Batch create/update metadata documents with empty tags array
// 3. Show one-time "Indexing files..." progress modal
// 4. Set taggedBy: "manual" and tagCount: 0 for all existing files
// 5. Cache indexing completion in localStorage to avoid re-runs
```

## Integration Points

### Existing Systems
- **Upload System**: Leverage existing file metadata and hash-based deduplication
- **Authentication**: Use existing team-based isolation (teamId === userId for solo users)
- **Storage**: Connect to existing Firebase Storage for file access
- **Routing**: Integrate with existing Vue Router and navigation

### Future Versions
- Tag structure extensible to category-based system (v1.1)
- Component architecture supports AI integration (v1.3)
- Data model compatible with confidence scoring (v1.4)
- UI framework supports virtual folder views (v1.2)

## Success Criteria

### Functional Requirements
- [ ] Users can view all uploaded files in organized list
- [ ] Users can assign text-based tags to any file
- [ ] Users can search/filter files by tag text
- [ ] System maintains existing upload functionality
- [ ] All operations respect team-based data isolation

### Performance Requirements
- [ ] File list loads within 2 seconds for 100 files
- [ ] Tag filtering responds within 500ms
- [ ] Tag assignment saves within 1 second
- [ ] UI remains responsive during all operations

### User Experience Requirements
- [ ] Intuitive interface requiring minimal learning
- [ ] Consistent with existing application design patterns
- [ ] Clear visual feedback for all user actions
- [ ] Graceful error handling and recovery

## Risk Mitigation

### Technical Risks
- **Large File Collections**: Start with client-side filtering, monitor performance
- **Concurrent Tag Updates**: Implement optimistic updates with rollback capability
- **Firestore Costs**: Monitor query patterns and implement pagination if needed

### User Experience Risks
- **Feature Discoverability**: Clear navigation and introductory help text
- **Tag Management Complexity**: Keep v1.0 simple, defer advanced features to later versions
- **Data Migration**: Ensure existing uploaded files are properly indexed

## Documentation Requirements

### Developer Documentation
- Component API documentation
- Store structure and actions
- Data model and relationships
- Testing guidelines and examples

### User Documentation
- Feature introduction and benefits
- Step-by-step usage guide
- Tag best practices
- Integration with existing workflow

## Deployment Strategy

### Development Phases
1. **Local Development**: Build and test all components in isolation
2. **Integration Testing**: Test with existing system on development Firebase
3. **User Acceptance Testing**: Deploy to staging environment for feedback
4. **Production Deployment**: Roll out with feature flag capability

### Rollback Plan
- Feature toggle for organizer navigation item
- Database schema changes are additive only
- Component lazy loading allows graceful fallback
- Separate service worker for organizer-specific functionality

## Timeline Estimation

### Week 1: Foundation
- Data model design and Firestore setup
- Basic component structure
- Store implementation and integration

### Week 2: Core Features
- File list display and tag input
- Basic search/filter functionality
- Navigation integration

### Week 3: Polish and Testing
- UI refinement and responsive design
- Comprehensive testing suite
- Performance optimization and error handling

### Total Estimated Duration: 3 weeks

This implementation plan provides the foundation for all future Organizer versions while delivering immediate value through manual document organization capabilities.

content.content:
1→# Organizer Feature Reference Document
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→The **Organizer** is an AI-powered document discovery and organization system designed to help users find previously uploaded files through intelligent categorization and flexible viewing interfaces. Rather than traditional folder storage, it uses a tag-based flat storage system with virtual folder presentations optimized for legal document management workflows.
     6→
     7→## Core Purpose
     8→
     9→**Primary Goal**: Enable users to quickly locate previously uploaded documents through intuitive search and categorization methods.
    10→
    11→**Target Use Cases**:
    12→- Finding bank statements by institution and account details
    13→- Locating photographs by location and date
    14→- Tracking document relationships (amendments, responses to letters)
    15→- Organizing documents for legal disclosure and trial preparation
    16→
    17→## Architecture Overview
    18→
    19→### Storage Strategy
    20→- **File Storage**: Continues using Storage 1 (existing Firebase Storage)
    21→- **Evidence Database**: New Firestore collection for organization metadata
    22→- **Reference Architecture**: Evidence entries point to files via fileHash
    23→- **No File Duplication**: Multiple evidence entries can reference same stored file
    24→- **Processing States**: Evidence tracks document through processing workflow
    25→
    26→### Processing Workflow
    27→1. **Manual Trigger**: Users select folders/batches for AI processing (not automatic)
    28→2. **AI Categorization**: Gemini multimodal API processes all file types uniformly
    29→3. **Confidence-Based Routing**: High confidence → auto-categorized, low confidence → human review
    30→4. **Context-Enhanced Processing**: Medium confidence files use previously categorized documents as examples
    31→
    32→## Tag System Design
    33→
    34→### Category Structure
    35→- **Categories**: User-defined groupings (e.g., "Document Type", "Date", "Institution")
    36→- **Tags**: Mutually exclusive options within each category (e.g., "Invoice", "Statement", "Contract")
    37→- **Color Coding**: Each category assigned distinct colors with gradient/border variations for scalability
    38→
    39→### Tag Management
    40→- **User-Defined Categories**: Users create custom categories with their own tag options
    41→- **Add/Delete Operations**: 
    42→  - Adding tags prompts for reprocessing existing documents
    43→  - Deleting tags requires reassignment decision for affected files
    44→- **Merge Capability**: Achieved through delete operations with reprocessing options
    45→
    46→### AI Processing Approach
    47→- **Unified Processing**: All file types processed through Gemini's multimodal capabilities
    48→- **No File-Type Optimization**: Avoid premature optimization that becomes obsolete as AI improves
    49→- **No Size Limits**: Large files processed normally; testing will determine practical constraints
    50→- **Two-Pass Algorithm**:
    51→  1. **High Confidence Pass**: >90% confidence files categorized immediately
    52→  2. **Context-Enhanced Pass**: Medium confidence files use previously categorized examples
    53→
    54→## User Interface Design
    55→
    56→### Flat View (Default)
    57→- **File List**: Filename, file extension, document date, all applicable tags
    58→- **Color-Coded Tags**: Tags colored by category for visual grouping
    59→- **Progressive Disclosure**: Right-click any tag → "Show in Folders" creates virtual folder structure
    60→
    61→### Virtual Folder View
    62→- **Dynamic Hierarchy**: User-selected tag categories become folder levels
    63→- **Filtered Display**: Only relevant tags shown (folder context already established)
    64→- **Navigation**: Breadcrumbs + back buttons for easy hierarchy traversal
    65→- **Instant Reorganization**: Change folder hierarchy instantly (just re-presenting same tag data)
    66→
    67→### File Actions (KISS Principle)
    68→- **View**: Document viewer with zoom, pagination (PDFs)
    69→- **Print to PDF**: BATES-stamped output (not raw download)
    70→- **No Thumbnails**: Keep interface fast and simple for document-focused workflow
    71→
    72→## Human Review System
    73→
    74→### Uncertainty Handling
    75→- **Review Folder**: "Human Review Required" category for uncertain classifications
    76→- **Confidence Thresholds**: User-adjustable sensitivity settings
    77→- **Review Interface**: 
    78→  - Top 3 AI suggestions with confidence percentages
    79→  - "Other" option for complete misclassification
    80→  - "Create New Category" for expanding taxonomy
    81→
    82→### Learning Approach
    83→- **No Model Training**: System doesn't fine-tune or retrain AI models
    84→- **Context Enhancement**: Uses human-reviewed examples as context for future medium-confidence decisions
    85→- **Human Priority**: Human classifications weighted higher than AI classifications in context examples
    86→
    87→## BATES Numbering System
    88→
    89→### Legal Workflow Integration
    90→- **Print-Only Access**: No raw downloads; only BATES-stamped PDF prints
    91→- **Disclosure Control**: Prevent confusion about document processing status in legal proceedings
    92→- **Format Flexibility**: [Optional Letter Prefix]-[Optional Document Number]-[Sequential Number]
    93→  - Examples: "Roberts-0001", "1.22-0003", "Plaintiff-1.22-0003"
    94→
    95→### Numbering Rules
    96→- **Sequential by Matter**: Each prefix/matter maintains independent sequential numbering
    97→- **Immutable Assignment**: BATES numbers "pencilled in" after processing, "inked" after first print
    98→- **Reprint Consistency**: Same document always prints same BATES number
    99→- **No Reassignment**: Once printed, BATES number permanently locked
   100→- **Reset Protection**: New prefix required for numbering resets; old prefixes never reused
   101→
   102→### Deduplication Integration
   103→- **Hash-Based Prevention**: Upload system prevents duplicate file uploads
   104→- **Near-Duplicate Handling**: Similar but different files each receive unique BATES numbers
   105→
   106→## Integration with Document Processing Workflow
   107→
   108→### Evidence Database Role
   109→- **Central Registry**: All processed documents tracked in Evidence database
   110→- **Processing Status**: Tracks files through upload → split → merge pipeline
   111→- **Quality Tracking**: Records hasAllPages and completeness status
   112→- **Multi-Storage Support**: References files across uploads/split/merged folders
   113→
   114→### Version 1.0 Preparation
   115→- Evidence schema includes processing fields (unused in v1.0)
   116→- Storage reference structure supports future split/merged folders
   117→- Processing status defaults to "uploaded" for all v1.0 entries
   118→- Future versions update these fields without schema changes
   119→
   120→## Technical Implementation Approach
   121→
   122→### AI Integration
   123→- **Primary API**: Google Gemini for multimodal document processing
   124→- **Processing Strategy**: Let Gemini handle file-type optimization internally
   125→- **Future-Proof Design**: Avoid custom optimization that becomes obsolete as AI improves
   126→
   127→### Data Storage
   128→- **Firebase Integration**: Leverage existing authentication and storage infrastructure
   129→- **Evidence Database**: New Firestore collection `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
   130→- **Storage References**: Evidence documents reference files in Storage 1 via:
   131→  - `storage`: Which storage folder (uploads/split/merged)
   132→  - `fileHash`: Unique file identifier
   133→  - `matterId`: Matter context for access control
   134→- **Processing Metadata**: Evidence tracks isProcessed, hasAllPages, processingStage
   135→- **Tag Storage**: All organizational data lives in Evidence, not upload metadata
   136→- **Team Isolation**: All data scoped by team ID (solo users: teamId === userId)
   137→
   138→### Performance Considerations
   139→- **Background Processing**: AI calls handled asynchronously with progress tracking
   140→- **Instant UI Updates**: Virtual folder reorganization requires no backend processing
   141→- **Scalable Visuals**: Gradient colors and borders provide unlimited category combinations
   142→
   143→## User Stories
   144→
   145→### Document Discovery Stories
   146→
   147→**As a lawyer, I want to find bank statements by institution and account details**
   148→- Given I have uploaded hundreds of financial documents
   149→- When I need to find Royal Bank of Canada statements for account ending in 334
   150→- Then I can use tags to filter by "Institution: RBC" and "Account: ...334"
   151→- So that I can quickly locate the specific statements without manually searching through files
   152→
   153→**As a legal professional, I want to locate photographs by location and date**
   154→- Given I have uploaded many photographs as evidence
   155→- When I need to find photos taken at Whistler Mountain in June 2017
   156→- Then I can filter by "Location: Whistler Mountain" and "Date: June 2017" tags
   157→- So that I can present the relevant photographic evidence
   158→
   159→**As a lawyer, I want to track document relationships and follow-ups**
   160→- Given I sent a letter requesting information and never received a response
   161→- When I need to follow up on unanswered correspondence
   162→- Then I can search for my original letter and check for any response documents
   163→- So that I can determine how long the request has been pending and take appropriate action
   164→
   165→**As a legal professional, I want to find all amendments to a contract**
   166→- Given I have a promissory note with multiple amendments
   167→- When I need to review all versions and modifications
   168→- Then I can find the original document and all related amendment documents
   169→- So that I have a complete view of the document's evolution
   170→
   171→### Category Management Stories
   172→
   173→**As a user, I want to create custom document categories**
   174→- Given I have unique document types specific to my practice
   175→- When I create a new "Document Type" category
   176→- Then I can define custom tags like "Affidavit", "Motion", "Brief"
   177→- So that my organization system matches my specific workflow needs
   178→
   179→**As a user, I want to add new tag options to existing categories**
   180→- Given I encounter a new type of document not in my current system
   181→- When I add a "Receipt" tag to my "Document Type" category
   182→- Then the system asks if I want to reprocess existing documents
   183→- So that previously uploaded receipts can be properly categorized
   184→
   185→**As a user, I want to merge duplicate category options**
   186→- Given I created both "Invoice" and "Bill" tags but realize they're the same
   187→- When I delete the "Bill" tag and choose to reprocess affected documents
   188→- Then all documents previously tagged as "Bill" are reconsidered for "Invoice"
   189→- So that I can consolidate my categorization scheme without losing data
   190→
   191→### AI Processing Stories
   192→
   193→**As a user, I want to process documents in batches by category type**
   194→- Given I have uploaded a folder of mixed financial documents
   195→- When I select the folder and choose "Document Type" processing
   196→- Then the AI categorizes documents as statements, invoices, receipts, etc.
   197→- So that I can organize large batches efficiently without manual sorting
   198→
   199→**As a user, I want to review uncertain AI classifications**
   200→- Given the AI is less than 90% confident about some document categorizations
   201→- When I access the "Human Review Required" folder
   202→- Then I see the top 3 AI suggestions with confidence percentages
   203→- So that I can quickly correct misclassifications and improve system accuracy
   204→
   205→**As a user, I want the system to learn from my corrections**
   206→- Given I have manually classified several uncertain documents
   207→- When the AI processes similar documents with medium confidence
   208→- Then it uses my previous classifications as context examples
   209→- So that the system becomes more accurate for my specific document types
   210→
   211→### Interface Navigation Stories
   212→
   213→**As a user, I want to start with a comprehensive flat view**
   214→- Given I have many documents with various tags
   215→- When I first access the organizer
   216→- Then I see all files with color-coded tags by category
   217→- So that I can understand my entire document collection at a glance
   218→
   219→**As a user, I want to create folder views by clicking on tags**
   220→- Given I see documents with various "Document Type" tags in flat view
   221→- When I right-click on a "Statement" tag and select "Show in Folders"
   222→- Then my view reorganizes into folders by document type
   223→- So that I can browse documents in a familiar folder structure
   224→
   225→**As a user, I want to drill down through multiple folder levels**
   226→- Given I have organized by "Document Type" and want to sub-organize by date
   227→- When I right-click on a "2023" tag and select "Show in Folders"
   228→- Then I get a hierarchy like "Statement > 2023 > March"
   229→- So that I can narrow down to very specific document sets
   230→
   231→**As a user, I want to instantly reorganize my folder hierarchy**
   232→- Given I have documents organized by Type > Date
   233→- When I decide I want them organized by Date > Type instead
   234→- Then the reorganization happens instantly without processing delays
   235→- So that I can experiment with different organizational schemes efficiently
   236→
   237→### BATES Numbering Stories
   238→
   239→**As a lawyer, I want to print documents with BATES stamps for disclosure**
   240→- Given I need to provide document disclosure for trial
   241→- When I print any document from the organizer
   242→- Then it includes a BATES number like "Roberts-0001" 
   243→- So that I can track disclosed documents and prevent disclosure confusion
   244→
   245→**As a legal professional, I want consistent BATES numbering per matter**
   246→- Given I'm working on multiple legal matters
   247→- When I set different prefixes for each case (e.g., "Smith-", "Jones-")
   248→- Then each case maintains its own sequential numbering
   249→- So that documents are properly organized by matter
   250→
   251→**As a lawyer, I want permanent BATES number assignment**
   252→- Given I've printed a document with BATES number "Roberts-0001"
   253→- When I print the same document again later
   254→- Then it always prints with the same BATES number
   255→- So that I maintain consistency in legal proceedings
   256→
   257→**As a user, I want protection against BATES numbering mistakes**
   258→- Given I need to restart my BATES numbering due to an error
   259→- When I create a new prefix for the same matter
   260→- Then the old prefix is permanently retired and cannot be reused
   261→- So that there's no confusion about which numbering sequence is current
   262→
   263→### Human Review Interface Stories
   264→
   265→**As a user, I want simple review options for uncertain documents**
   266→- Given the AI presents a document with uncertain classification
   267→- When I see the 3 AI suggestions plus "Other" and "Create New Category" buttons
   268→- Then I can quickly select the correct option or create a new one
   269→- So that document review is fast and doesn't interrupt my workflow
   270→
   271→**As a user, I want to create new categories during review**
   272→- Given I encounter a document type not in my current system
   273→- When I click "Create New Category" during human review
   274→- Then the system asks if I want to reprocess other documents for this new category
   275→- So that I can expand my taxonomy as I discover new document types
   276→
   277→### Legal Workflow Stories
   278→
   279→**As a lawyer, I want to prevent raw document downloads**
   280→- Given clients or opposing parties might create confusion with untracked copies
   281→- When I access any document in the organizer
   282→- Then I can only print BATES-stamped versions, not download raw files
   283→- So that all document copies in circulation are properly tracked and identified
   284→
   285→**As a legal professional, I want to track document processing history**
   286→- Given I need to verify whether documents have been properly processed
   287→- When I review any document's metadata
   288→- Then I can see whether it was classified by AI or human review
   289→- So that I can ensure quality control in my document management process
   290→
   291→## User Experience Flow
   292→
   293→### Initial Setup
   294→1. User uploads documents through existing upload feature
   295→2. Documents appear in flat view with basic metadata
   296→3. User creates categories and defines tag options
   297→4. User selects document batches for AI processing
   298→
   299→### Processing Workflow
   300→1. User selects folder/batch and processing category
   301→2. AI processes documents with confidence-based routing
   302→3. High confidence: Auto-categorized
   303→4. Medium confidence: Context-enhanced processing using previous examples
   304→5. Low confidence: Routed to human review folder
   305→6. User reviews uncertain classifications via simple 5-button interface
   306→
   307→### Organization and Discovery
   308→1. User starts in flat view seeing all tags
   309→2. Right-click any tag → "Show in Folders" to create hierarchy
   310→3. Navigate through virtual folder structure
   311→4. Find target document and view/print with BATES numbering
   312→

# Organizer Feature Reference Document

## Overview

The **Organizer** is an AI-powered document discovery and organization system designed to help users find previously uploaded files through intelligent categorization and flexible viewing interfaces. Rather than traditional folder storage, it uses a tag-based flat storage system with virtual folder presentations optimized for legal document management workflows.

## Core Purpose

**Primary Goal**: Enable users to quickly locate previously uploaded documents through intuitive search and categorization methods.

**Target Use Cases**:
- Finding bank statements by institution and account details
- Locating photographs by location and date
- Tracking document relationships (amendments, responses to letters)
- Organizing documents for legal disclosure and trial preparation

## Architecture Overview

### Storage Strategy
- **File Storage**: Continues using Storage 1 (existing Firebase Storage)
- **Evidence Database**: New Firestore collection for organization metadata
- **Reference Architecture**: Evidence entries point to files via fileHash
- **No File Duplication**: Multiple evidence entries can reference same stored file
- **Processing States**: Evidence tracks document through processing workflow

### Processing Workflow
1. **Manual Trigger**: Users select folders/batches for AI processing (not automatic)
2. **AI Categorization**: Gemini multimodal API processes all file types uniformly
3. **Confidence-Based Routing**: High confidence → auto-categorized, low confidence → human review
4. **Context-Enhanced Processing**: Medium confidence files use previously categorized documents as examples

## Tag System Design

### Category Structure
- **Categories**: User-defined groupings (e.g., "Document Type", "Date", "Institution")
- **Tags**: Mutually exclusive options within each category (e.g., "Invoice", "Statement", "Contract")
- **Color Coding**: Each category assigned distinct colors with gradient/border variations for scalability

### Tag Management
- **User-Defined Categories**: Users create custom categories with their own tag options
- **Add/Delete Operations**: 
  - Adding tags prompts for reprocessing existing documents
  - Deleting tags requires reassignment decision for affected files
- **Merge Capability**: Achieved through delete operations with reprocessing options

### AI Processing Approach
- **Unified Processing**: All file types processed through Gemini's multimodal capabilities
- **No File-Type Optimization**: Avoid premature optimization that becomes obsolete as AI improves
- **No Size Limits**: Large files processed normally; testing will determine practical constraints
- **Two-Pass Algorithm**:
  1. **High Confidence Pass**: >90% confidence files categorized immediately
  2. **Context-Enhanced Pass**: Medium confidence files use previously categorized examples

## User Interface Design

### Flat View (Default)
- **File List**: Filename, file extension, document date, all applicable tags
- **Color-Coded Tags**: Tags colored by category for visual grouping
- **Progressive Disclosure**: Right-click any tag → "Show in Folders" creates virtual folder structure

### Virtual Folder View
- **Dynamic Hierarchy**: User-selected tag categories become folder levels
- **Filtered Display**: Only relevant tags shown (folder context already established)
- **Navigation**: Breadcrumbs + back buttons for easy hierarchy traversal
- **Instant Reorganization**: Change folder hierarchy instantly (just re-presenting same tag data)

### File Actions (KISS Principle)
- **View**: Document viewer with zoom, pagination (PDFs)
- **Print to PDF**: BATES-stamped output (not raw download)
- **No Thumbnails**: Keep interface fast and simple for document-focused workflow

## Human Review System

### Uncertainty Handling
- **Review Folder**: "Human Review Required" category for uncertain classifications
- **Confidence Thresholds**: User-adjustable sensitivity settings
- **Review Interface**: 
  - Top 3 AI suggestions with confidence percentages
  - "Other" option for complete misclassification
  - "Create New Category" for expanding taxonomy

### Learning Approach
- **No Model Training**: System doesn't fine-tune or retrain AI models
- **Context Enhancement**: Uses human-reviewed examples as context for future medium-confidence decisions
- **Human Priority**: Human classifications weighted higher than AI classifications in context examples

## BATES Numbering System

### Legal Workflow Integration
- **Print-Only Access**: No raw downloads; only BATES-stamped PDF prints
- **Disclosure Control**: Prevent confusion about document processing status in legal proceedings
- **Format Flexibility**: [Optional Letter Prefix]-[Optional Document Number]-[Sequential Number]
  - Examples: "Roberts-0001", "1.22-0003", "Plaintiff-1.22-0003"

### Numbering Rules
- **Sequential by Matter**: Each prefix/matter maintains independent sequential numbering
- **Immutable Assignment**: BATES numbers "pencilled in" after processing, "inked" after first print
- **Reprint Consistency**: Same document always prints same BATES number
- **No Reassignment**: Once printed, BATES number permanently locked
- **Reset Protection**: New prefix required for numbering resets; old prefixes never reused

### Deduplication Integration
- **Hash-Based Prevention**: Upload system prevents duplicate file uploads
- **Near-Duplicate Handling**: Similar but different files each receive unique BATES numbers

## Integration with Document Processing Workflow

### Evidence Database Role
- **Central Registry**: All processed documents tracked in Evidence database
- **Processing Status**: Tracks files through upload → split → merge pipeline
- **Quality Tracking**: Records hasAllPages and completeness status
- **Multi-Storage Support**: References files across uploads/split/merged folders

### Version 1.0 Preparation
- Evidence schema includes processing fields (unused in v1.0)
- Storage reference structure supports future split/merged folders
- Processing status defaults to "uploaded" for all v1.0 entries
- Future versions update these fields without schema changes

## Technical Implementation Approach

### AI Integration
- **Primary API**: Google Gemini for multimodal document processing
- **Processing Strategy**: Let Gemini handle file-type optimization internally
- **Future-Proof Design**: Avoid custom optimization that becomes obsolete as AI improves

### Data Storage
- **Firebase Integration**: Leverage existing authentication and storage infrastructure
- **Evidence Database**: New Firestore collection `/teams/{teamId}/evidence/`
- **Storage References**: Evidence documents reference files in Storage 1 via:
  - `storage`: Which storage folder (uploads/split/merged)
  - `fileHash`: Unique file identifier
  - `matterId`: Matter context for access control
- **Processing Metadata**: Evidence tracks isProcessed, hasAllPages, processingStage
- **Tag Storage**: All organizational data lives in Evidence, not upload metadata
- **Team Isolation**: All data scoped by team ID (solo users: teamId === userId)

### Performance Considerations
- **Background Processing**: AI calls handled asynchronously with progress tracking
- **Instant UI Updates**: Virtual folder reorganization requires no backend processing
- **Scalable Visuals**: Gradient colors and borders provide unlimited category combinations

## User Stories

### Document Discovery Stories

**As a lawyer, I want to find bank statements by institution and account details**
- Given I have uploaded hundreds of financial documents
- When I need to find Royal Bank of Canada statements for account ending in 334
- Then I can use tags to filter by "Institution: RBC" and "Account: ...334"
- So that I can quickly locate the specific statements without manually searching through files

**As a legal professional, I want to locate photographs by location and date**
- Given I have uploaded many photographs as evidence
- When I need to find photos taken at Whistler Mountain in June 2017
- Then I can filter by "Location: Whistler Mountain" and "Date: June 2017" tags
- So that I can present the relevant photographic evidence

**As a lawyer, I want to track document relationships and follow-ups**
- Given I sent a letter requesting information and never received a response
- When I need to follow up on unanswered correspondence
- Then I can search for my original letter and check for any response documents
- So that I can determine how long the request has been pending and take appropriate action

**As a legal professional, I want to find all amendments to a contract**
- Given I have a promissory note with multiple amendments
- When I need to review all versions and modifications
- Then I can find the original document and all related amendment documents
- So that I have a complete view of the document's evolution

### Category Management Stories

**As a user, I want to create custom document categories**
- Given I have unique document types specific to my practice
- When I create a new "Document Type" category
- Then I can define custom tags like "Affidavit", "Motion", "Brief"
- So that my organization system matches my specific workflow needs

**As a user, I want to add new tag options to existing categories**
- Given I encounter a new type of document not in my current system
- When I add a "Receipt" tag to my "Document Type" category
- Then the system asks if I want to reprocess existing documents
- So that previously uploaded receipts can be properly categorized

**As a user, I want to merge duplicate category options**
- Given I created both "Invoice" and "Bill" tags but realize they're the same
- When I delete the "Bill" tag and choose to reprocess affected documents
- Then all documents previously tagged as "Bill" are reconsidered for "Invoice"
- So that I can consolidate my categorization scheme without losing data

### AI Processing Stories

**As a user, I want to process documents in batches by category type**
- Given I have uploaded a folder of mixed financial documents
- When I select the folder and choose "Document Type" processing
- Then the AI categorizes documents as statements, invoices, receipts, etc.
- So that I can organize large batches efficiently without manual sorting

**As a user, I want to review uncertain AI classifications**
- Given the AI is less than 90% confident about some document categorizations
- When I access the "Human Review Required" folder
- Then I see the top 3 AI suggestions with confidence percentages
- So that I can quickly correct misclassifications and improve system accuracy

**As a user, I want the system to learn from my corrections**
- Given I have manually classified several uncertain documents
- When the AI processes similar documents with medium confidence
- Then it uses my previous classifications as context examples
- So that the system becomes more accurate for my specific document types

### Interface Navigation Stories

**As a user, I want to start with a comprehensive flat view**
- Given I have many documents with various tags
- When I first access the organizer
- Then I see all files with color-coded tags by category
- So that I can understand my entire document collection at a glance

**As a user, I want to create folder views by clicking on tags**
- Given I see documents with various "Document Type" tags in flat view
- When I right-click on a "Statement" tag and select "Show in Folders"
- Then my view reorganizes into folders by document type
- So that I can browse documents in a familiar folder structure

**As a user, I want to drill down through multiple folder levels**
- Given I have organized by "Document Type" and want to sub-organize by date
- When I right-click on a "2023" tag and select "Show in Folders"
- Then I get a hierarchy like "Statement > 2023 > March"
- So that I can narrow down to very specific document sets

**As a user, I want to instantly reorganize my folder hierarchy**
- Given I have documents organized by Type > Date
- When I decide I want them organized by Date > Type instead
- Then the reorganization happens instantly without processing delays
- So that I can experiment with different organizational schemes efficiently

### BATES Numbering Stories

**As a lawyer, I want to print documents with BATES stamps for disclosure**
- Given I need to provide document disclosure for trial
- When I print any document from the organizer
- Then it includes a BATES number like "Roberts-0001" 
- So that I can track disclosed documents and prevent disclosure confusion

**As a legal professional, I want consistent BATES numbering per matter**
- Given I'm working on multiple legal matters
- When I set different prefixes for each case (e.g., "Smith-", "Jones-")
- Then each case maintains its own sequential numbering
- So that documents are properly organized by matter

**As a lawyer, I want permanent BATES number assignment**
- Given I've printed a document with BATES number "Roberts-0001"
- When I print the same document again later
- Then it always prints with the same BATES number
- So that I maintain consistency in legal proceedings

**As a user, I want protection against BATES numbering mistakes**
- Given I need to restart my BATES numbering due to an error
- When I create a new prefix for the same matter
- Then the old prefix is permanently retired and cannot be reused
- So that there's no confusion about which numbering sequence is current

### Human Review Interface Stories

**As a user, I want simple review options for uncertain documents**
- Given the AI presents a document with uncertain classification
- When I see the 3 AI suggestions plus "Other" and "Create New Category" buttons
- Then I can quickly select the correct option or create a new one
- So that document review is fast and doesn't interrupt my workflow

**As a user, I want to create new categories during review**
- Given I encounter a document type not in my current system
- When I click "Create New Category" during human review
- Then the system asks if I want to reprocess other documents for this new category
- So that I can expand my taxonomy as I discover new document types

### Legal Workflow Stories

**As a lawyer, I want to prevent raw document downloads**
- Given clients or opposing parties might create confusion with untracked copies
- When I access any document in the organizer
- Then I can only print BATES-stamped versions, not download raw files
- So that all document copies in circulation are properly tracked and identified

**As a legal professional, I want to track document processing history**
- Given I need to verify whether documents have been properly processed
- When I review any document's metadata
- Then I can see whether it was classified by AI or human review
- So that I can ensure quality control in my document management process

## User Experience Flow

### Initial Setup
1. User uploads documents through existing upload feature
2. Documents appear in flat view with basic metadata
3. User creates categories and defines tag options
4. User selects document batches for AI processing

### Processing Workflow
1. User selects folder/batch and processing category
2. AI processes documents with confidence-based routing
3. High confidence: Auto-categorized
4. Medium confidence: Context-enhanced processing using previous examples
5. Low confidence: Routed to human review folder
6. User reviews uncertain classifications via simple 5-button interface

### Organization and Discovery
1. User starts in flat view seeing all tags
2. Right-click any tag → "Show in Folders" to create hierarchy
3. Navigate through virtual folder structure
4. Find target document and view/print with BATES numbering

## Success Metrics

### User Efficiency
- Time to locate specific documents
- Reduction in manual file organization effort
- Accuracy of AI categorization after context enhancement

### Legal Workflow Support
- Document disclosure completeness
- BATES numbering consistency
- Prevention of duplicate processing confusion

### System Performance
- AI processing accuracy by confidence threshold
- User override rates in human review
- Virtual folder reorganization response times

## Future Enhancements

### Automation Options
- Optional automatic processing mode when AI reliability improves
- User-configurable automation rules and triggers

### Advanced Features
- Cross-document relationship tracking
- Bulk download with virtual folder structure preservation
- Integration with external legal case management systems

### Scalability
- Multi-user team support (extending solo team architecture)
- Advanced search across tag combinations
- Audit trails for document access and modifications

## Technical Dependencies

### External Services
- Google Gemini API for multimodal document processing
- Firebase Auth/Firestore/Storage for data management

### Existing Codebase Integration
- Builds on established upload feature and deduplication system
- Leverages existing Vue 3/Vuetify component architecture
- Integrates with solo team authentication model

### Development Approach
- Follow KISS principle throughout implementation
- Prefer simple solutions over premature optimization
- Focus on legal workflow requirements and user experience

1→# Organizer Feature Implementation Phases
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→This document outlines the incremental implementation phases for the Organizer feature described in `Organizer-Feature-Reference.md`. Each version adds a single, well-scoped feature that builds upon previous versions without breaking existing functionality.
     6→
     7→## Version 1.0: Basic File Listing with Manual Tags
     8→
     9→**Core Goal**: Simple file list with manual tag assignment
    10→
    11→**Features**:
    12→- Basic file list view showing uploaded files (filename, extension, upload date)
    13→- Manual tag assignment interface - users can type tags for each file
    14→- Simple tag display (text-based, no colors)
    15→- Basic search/filter by tag text
    16→- Uses existing upload system and file storage
    17→
    18→**Implementation Scope**:
    19→- New "Organizer" view in navigation
    20→- File list component pulling from existing Firebase storage
    21→- Simple tag input field per file
    22→- Tags stored in Firestore as array of strings per file
    23→- Basic text-based filtering
    24→
    25→**User Flow**:
    26→1. User navigates to Organizer view
    27→2. Sees list of all uploaded files
    28→3. Clicks on a file to add tags (simple text input)
    29→4. Can filter file list by typing tag names
    30→
    31→---
    32→
    33→## Version 1.0.1: Quick Enhancements (Optional Minor Release)
    34→
    35→**Core Goal**: Iterate quickly on Version 1.0 based on user feedback
    36→
    37→**New Features**:
    38→- Bulk tag operations (select multiple files for batch tagging)
    39→- Tag autocomplete and recent tags list
    40→- Enhanced search with OR logic (find files with any of multiple tags)
    41→- Empty states and better loading indicators
    42→- Improved tag input UX (keyboard shortcuts, better validation)
    43→
    44→**Implementation Scope**:
    45→- Multi-select interface for file list
    46→- Autocomplete component for tag input
    47→- Enhanced search logic supporting multiple terms
    48→- Loading states and empty state components
    49→- UX polish and accessibility improvements
    50→
    51→**User Flow**:
    52→1. Select multiple files using checkboxes or Ctrl+click
    53→2. Apply tags to all selected files at once
    54→3. Use autocomplete for faster tag entry
    55→4. Search for files using multiple tag names (OR logic)
    56→5. See helpful messages when no files match filters
    57→
    58→**Timeline**: 1 week after v1.0 launch (based on user feedback)
    59→
    60→**Rationale**: Low-risk, high-value additions that ship quickly based on initial user feedback
    61→
    62→---
    63→
    64→## Version 1.1: Category-Based Tag System
    65→
    66→**Core Goal**: Structure tags into user-defined categories
    67→
    68→**New Features**:
    69→- Category creation interface (user defines category names like "Document Type", "Date")
    70→- Tags now belong to categories instead of being free-form text
    71→- Category management (add/edit/delete categories)
    72→- Tag assignment limited to predefined category options
    73→- Color coding by category (simple distinct colors)
    74→
    75→**Implementation Scope**:
    76→- Category management interface
    77→- Update tag storage to include category reference
    78→- Color assignment system for categories
    79→- Modified tag assignment UI to show category groupings
    80→
    81→**User Flow**:
    82→1. User creates categories (e.g., "Document Type", "Institution")
    83→2. For each category, defines available tags (e.g., "Invoice", "Statement")
    84→3. Tags files by selecting from category dropdown options
    85→4. Files display with color-coded tags grouped by category
    86→
    87→---
    88→
    89→## Version 1.2: AI Categorization (Manual Trigger)
    90→
    91→**Core Goal**: Let AI suggest tags for selected files
    92→
    93→**New Features**:
    94→- "Process with AI" button for selected files
    95→- Integration with Google Gemini API for document analysis
    96→- AI suggests tags based on existing category structure
    97→- Simple approval interface - user accepts or rejects AI suggestions
    98→- Manual processing only (user must trigger)
    99→
   100→**Implementation Scope**:
   101→- Gemini API integration
   102→- File selection interface
   103→- AI processing queue with progress tracking
   104→- Suggestion review interface
   105→- Batch processing capability
   106→
   107→**User Flow**:
   108→1. User selects files for AI processing
   109→2. Chooses which categories AI should analyze
   110→3. AI processes files and suggests appropriate tags
   111→4. User reviews and approves/rejects suggestions
   112→5. Approved tags are applied to files
   113→
   114→---
   115→
   116→## Version 1.3: Virtual Folder View
   117→
   118→**Core Goal**: Present tags as familiar folder structures
   119→
   120→**New Features**:
   121→- "Show in Folders" option when right-clicking tags
   122→- Dynamic folder hierarchy based on selected tag categories
   123→- Breadcrumb navigation in folder view

   126→
   127→**Implementation Scope**:
   128→- Folder view component

   133→**User Flow**:
   134→1. From flat view, right-click any tag and select "Show in Folders"
   135→2. View reorganizes into folder structure based on that tag category
   136→3. Navigate through folders using breadcrumbs
